author: Matt2790
review_text: Some nice storiew here and there but some others average too. Art and design, combat and music are excellent and it improves from the first one BUT, the high random encounter rate, and the lack of depth it gets repetitive after a few hours, especially once you unlock everyone skills.

author: Sabito7966
review_text:
Better than the first in every way it quickly became one of my favorite game of all times.

The gameplay, the visual and the soundtrack are amazing.

The story is quite cliché but it's still enjoyable and the JP voice acting is really great.

author: ASPlease
review_text: The beautiful artwork in irreplaceable HD-2D graphics and the combat experience that brings each character's personality to the turn-based battles is a great experience for fans of the past. The story of each hero is also more immersive than before, and the game is a masterpiece that improves on the mechanics and details that were lacking in its predecessor.

author: MaverickMc
review_text:
De alguna forma se las ingeniaron para hacer algo aún mejor de lo que fue la primera entrega, excelente tanto en el apartado artístico, incluyendo la historia, como en la jugabilidad, se superaron a si mismos
Lo único en lo que peca es que, al igual que en la primera entrega, no presenta un desafío real en ningún momento. No hubo un solo combate en que un boss me pusiera contra las cuerdas (o que siquiera requiriese esfuerzo), incluso debía desequiparme continuamente las habilidades del tipo "más experiencia" para no sobrelevelearme accidentalmente, aunque todo el resto de la experiencia de juego es tan gratificante que se lo perdono, el único motivo para no dar un 10/10 es la falta de un modo difícil (o sería más pertinente un modo normal, llamando dificultad historia a la aventura actual, aunque lo del nombre es lo de menos)

author: Soulcast
review_text:
Una auténtica maravilla de videojuego, jugarlo en steam deck no tiene precio.

Mejora todo lo que tiene su precuela, de lo mejor de este año sin lugar a dudas si el RPG clasico japones es vuestro rollo.

author: karnix
review_text: With beautiful graphics and one of the best ost I've heard, it improves on everything from the first one, with a deeper and more strategic combat and with much more endearing characters and stories than the first one.

author: kjloma
review_text: Best jrpg of this year, a deep combat system with a lot of customization that encourages experimentation, beautiful graphics and fantastic OST and stories and characters much better carried than in the previous one.

author: Valance23322
review_text: Expands and improves on the first game in nearly every way.  GOTY for me, the epilogue especially knocked it out of the park.

author: futureP
review_text:
Tag this game.
I'm preparing to play this game, but I haven't started playing yet. I'm just tagging this game so that I can find it easily when I play it in the future.

author: Dubeau
review_text: Octo II has a great narrative. The stories are interesting, mostly. Some are more boring then others. The stories are the main element for this game. The fighting is pure JRPG turn based. Some boss fights require some specials powers. The level of difficulty become a real grind at level 18, and in that sens, there is a lot of grinding when you arrive at the chapter 2 of each character, and chapter 3 is even more higher in terms of level. I don't feel like there is a natural way of levelling except grind. Which I found dull to no measure. The sounds are pretty good. The graphics are also very nice for a semi 2d game. I give it 72%. I liked the game, not so much the level of difficulty.

author: Frankie321
review_text:
Wow.  An immersive game world.  Not just an immersive game, but an immersive GAME world.  The next gen HD-2D graphics create a world that looks like a game world.  This game world looks greats and seems alive.  You know you're out of the real world and into a classic game world (but with better graphics).

There is not just one story, but eight individual stories plus the overall story.  The writing is good.  Each character is distinctive.  For example, one character is a dancer who wants to bring smiles to the world!  I've never seen anything like that before.  It's nice to see happy characters who want to bring joy to the world.  Yet, there's also a thief character, who says "heh, heh" as she steals from townspeople.  This is the first time I've experienced this combat based on a break the enemy system.  The game runs smoothly on my PC, never a game performance problem.  In sum, a top quality game by Square Enix's currently best (or one of the best) developers, Team Asano.  Note: you don't need to have played Octopath Traveller the original in order to play this one.

author: LaernuTairo
review_text:
Lol.
Niche game. And now a niche company.
Cannot believe the audacity of trying to pass off this game at 60$ and calling its ridiculous lack of texture detail an artistic decision, instead of what it really is, which is a cop out on putting real effort into a game.    Avoid at all costs.

review_text: 60$ for a game that cost 5$ and one dev a month to make

author: FoxForce
review_text:
Like the first game, the sequel is underdeveloped and overpriced. It is just a very generic JRPG.
It has improved but the price tag is still far higher than it is worth.

Square Enix like many other publishers constantly burn their resources then expect the customers to pay for overpriced products like this to make up for their incompetence.

author: turgaysenturk
review_text: Gris is a breathtakingly beautiful experience — more art piece than traditional game. The visuals are absolutely mesmerizing, with every frame looking like a watercolor painting come to life. The puzzles are simple yet elegant, blending seamlessly into the emotional journey rather than interrupting **** music ties everything together with haunting, emotional tracks that rise and fall with the story’s tone. Gris is a serene, visually stunning experience from start to finish.

author: Salqun
review_text: I wanted to play Neva and since Gris was really cheap I just decided to give it a try before buying it. I didn't come with much expectations but I almost cried at the end, the art direction is fantastic and the music is truly one of the best from an indie game. I find it a little short even as a Journey fan, I think that it could've been a little bit longer, especially with what the story is truly about. As for the simplicity of the gameplay, I think it suits the game quite nicely but I get that puzzles and platforming isn't for everyone.

author: Codename_48
review_text: Gris is a peaceful game. I love it. graphic art style is a masterpiece and music is insane! The story is conceptual and the gameplay has simple but worthy features mechanic. Its totally enjoyable, of course its short and some level environment are confusing a bit. but anyway I give it a complete score because it's what "the game is an art" means.

author: drlowdon
review_text: The gameplay is merely adequate, but the stunning water colour visuals and beautiful soundtrack ensure that GRIS is a memorable experience.

author: Sebasus
review_text: Beautiful, creative and relaxing game (the music is SO good and works together with the excellent design. Gameplay can be boring in some parts, but I think that this game is not something you play to have fun, this is something you play to relax your mind and appreciate art

author: Spyrou
review_text:
Profound story on loss and recovery which may be interpreted differently by players. 
Simple mechanics: Nice learning curve and lots of good ideas in the puzzles.
Great art style: both graphics and sounds. 
A relaxing game, not too challenging. 
Personal warning: the themes could trigger some individuals, about sadness.

author: KillerTeddyB3ar
review_text: The feeling of being stuck in what feels like a lifeless, emotionless, and completely uncaring world, where your voice and feelings mean nothing, is a feeling that I unfortunately believe many (if not all) people in this world have felt. Whether it's a feeling manifested by loss, disappointment, anger, a chemical imbalance in your brain, disease, depression, or any of the other thousands of reasons is ultimately irrelevant. The point is that most people have felt this feeling in their own unique way. GRIS starts with that exact feeling. A character that sees no colour in the world, no life, no meaning, and no voice of her own, with trials and tribulations designed in a way that actively set her back, trying to impede her progress. Gameplay-wise, many of these obstacles are very easy to deal with. However, metaphorically, whenever Gris overcomes these setbacks, she heals a tiny bit of her psyche. More and more life, colour, and joy is brought back into her world, which is beautifully realised with both the gorgeous art design and a sublime soundtrack composed by the band Berlinist. And while I don't believe every idea present in this game is 100% cohesive, nor do I believe the gameplay is all that engaging or well intertwined with the story, the game is still a sublime work of art and an impressive debut from Nomada Studio.

author: Zareli
review_text:
I got this because it was by Devolver Digital, a mistake.
Boring, pretentious, criptic in a bad way, slow, intentionally padded to enlengthen it for no reason other than showcase the graphics and artwork that honestly are nothing to be amazed at. 
I felt nothing more than regret while playing this.

author: RivaGe
review_text: When I was 7, my late uncle Dimytro used to make me shovel pig manure all day on his farm. Even then, I had more fun than playing this game.

author: RealNova
review_text: You will not play until the last 15% of the game, for 85% you do nothing but hold forward and do a few of the most basic jumps possible.

Edit: i forgot to say that if you want to know the history of the protagonist you have to go on the wiki because there are no dialogues and from the game itself you can't understand the story

I am sorry if i made any mistakes English is not my first language i am Italian

author: Zime
review_text: A pretty art piece, but a severly lacking video game.

author: TheW4tchT0wer
review_text: I know why journalists loved this garbage - it's barely even a game. For my brief time playing, I held the control stick to the right and maybe hit the jump button a few dozen times. It's an art project that results from sniffing one's own farts for way too long. Just make an animated short next time and don't try to charge $15 for this awful pretend-game.

author: egeiscimen
review_text: Boldly reinvents the series with turn-based combat. Pacing and grind can be an issue but it’s full of charm.

author: Zelou
review_text:
A história desse jogo é muito boa, nesse sentido, manteve o nível de entradas anteriores. Todos os personagens são muito interessantes e vivos, com características únicas.

O grande problema desse jogo, para mim, fica em algumas partes do combate. A batalha contra os chefões não são muito divertidas, acabam se tornando extremamente longas e repetitivas. Talvez seja uma limitação do estilo de combate por turno, porém isso teve um impacto negativo para mim em determinados momentos do jogo.

Considerando tudo, foi um ótimo jogo, o universo é muito vivo e existem inúmeras atividades para fazer além da história principal. Inclusive, existem tantas coisas para fazer, que o jogo acaba se tornando grande e demorado até demais. Para quem é muito fã, certamente consegue ficar centenas de horas sem enjoar.

author: ghost91214
review_text: Yakuza: Like a Dragon ist ein fantastischer Startpunkt für alle, die neu in die Yakuza-Welt eintauchen wollen. Das Spiel bricht mit Traditionen und liefert ein einzigartiges Erlebnis. Der neue Held, Ichiban Kasuga, ist einfach Gold wert. Sein grenzenloser Optimismus und seine "Golden Retriever"-Energie sind unglaublich sympathisch und geben der Story eine ganz besondere Note. Die Geschichte ist packend und tiefgründig. Auch wenn sich das Erzähltempo manchmal etwas zieht, lohnt es sich, dranzubleiben – die Charaktere und Wendungen sind es wert. Besonders hervorzuheben ist das Gameplay: Der Wechsel zu rundenbasierten Kämpfen ist überraschend witzig und macht einfach Spaß. Es ist eine erfrischende Abwechslung, die dem Spiel seinen ganz eigenen Charme verleiht. Yakuza: Like a Dragon ist ein absolutes Highlight – ein einzigartiges JRPG mit Herz, Humor und einem unvergesslichen Protagonisten. Sehr empfehlenswert!

author: warioenthusiast
review_text: Yakuza: Like a Dragon gets 93 Wario Points from I, The Wario Enthusiast. This is a Wario Worthy game

author: basic12345
review_text: Superb story and good gameplay. Fighting can get a little bit boring after a while. But overall a nice game and a big surprise.

author: Blank1369
review_text:
they took a huge risk changing the genre as well as the iconic protagonist but for me they did it with flying colors
Pros:
-Unique and fun combat the turn based aspect allows them to go wild with their imaginations..nuclear bombs,dragons and a lot of goofy stuff along with it
-Great cast that develops a lot because of Ichiban

Cons:
-towards the end you will reach a heavy wall which requires you to grind a lot before trying the boss again

author: TheL0neW0If
review_text:
I do not like the fact that I had to give a yakuza game a negative rating.
Unlike previous games some characters lack depth and are in a way less serious to previous yakuza games.

the game combat system gets very repetitive and it is very slow. for people who use to play the game only for the sake of the main story, now have to be ready to grind a lot to be on the same level as the enemy.
combat system can leave you wanting to tear your hair and smash your head against the keyboard. a third of the time you will see your character running to the enemy and back to his position.

from my readings the developers had to change the project direction, because beat em up was not attracting enough players from the japanese market, but in doing so they took one of the core elements of the game.

the fights not only in the sub story but also in the main story became way too comical, a charachter would blow a kiss to an enemy lowering their defense stats, compared to the old games where majima or kiryu would scream furiously and charge their heat to pull sick moves.

the city is impressive as always the side activites too. the graphics is great, voice acting I can not complain always on point.

big minus points are the grinding you might need to spend 8 hours or so preparing for a fight. a fight can take 45 mins to an hour sometimes and it is less exciting and extremely repetitve, you would skip some turns with no action just to heal your charachters.

as someone who played yakuza from 0 until 7 I unfortunately might stop following the series or just watch a lets play on YouTube, because i can not put myself through a yakuza similar to like a dragon. I quit the game toward the last 3 or 2 chapters and started watching lets play while skipping the fights, during my own gameplay i left it on autopilot sometimes until fights finished and then I came back.

author: hertzian68
review_text: This game is a mixed bag but overall it's a banal excuse of a yakuza game when taken into account the other 7 games in the series. We go from the legends and high level yakuza glory and drama with a Kiryu of dignified tragic grandeur and the other legends and their stories to childlike **** and bums with endless UI and dialogue that just crawls along. GAG. The writers LOVE orphans, they love surrogate paternal relationships, they love all types of perversions and all sorts of  videogame culture, we get it this is just over the top and does NOT fit in very well with the series as a whole. I don't play turn based combat games, it's too automatic and too UI heavy I prefer control over the experience as much as possible with the least UI in the way. One aspect of why I've played and replayed 0-6 is that it's NOT TURN BASED. This is serviceable but I did NOT play Dragon Quest so the references mean nothing to me. Ichiban seems to SHOUT his lines rather than speak and it sounds like he's on drugs lol. The larger maps are pretty empty and generic, even reworked from Y4/Y5 to my eye. I think Y6 was about 40gb, this monster is 60gb and for what? so they can shout MA MORE! BLOATED. The back stories are just not believable, although that's true for most yakuza games to be fair. This game would have benefit by being shorter and more personal and detailed AND being more Yakuza focused rather than all the other characters etc that have absolutely no YA-KU-ZA whatsoever. Over-Rated. GARRISH. PERVERTED. BANAL.

author: pixeru
review_text:
10/10 character design
10/10 soundtrack
10/10 UI
10/10 story

What is not 10/10? The controls in PC. There's no problem if you're playing with controller (I've tried both!) :3

If you completed Nier Automata, you MUST replay it again in order to get the true grasp on what's going on. The first ending is just the tip of the iceberg.I am mainly into the UI design and the soundtrack, Hisayoshi Kijima is really killing this one, with both aesthetic and unique aspect of it.

And don't forget the character animations! Really unique and ughhhh.. Appealing! I LOVE YOU DEVELOPERRRRRSS

10/10 overall.

author: Marcozanella
review_text: Jogo excelente, belos gráficos, ótima história e jogabilidade bem fluida. Contém muitas missões secundárias que ampliam o conteúdo do jogo, que possuí diversos finais. Simplesmente imperdível, um dos melhores jogos de todos os tempos.

author: MrAzizi
review_text: I didn't like the game in the first hours and then when the story came into play I loved the game (Great Story). The only boring thing is that you have to finish the game 2-3 times, they should have combined them all directly.

author: Snell91
review_text:
I don't hate it, but I do feel the level of praise it's getting, i.e. compare to Elden Ring, Breath of the wild etc as a potentially top tier RPG hack n slash is a bit laughable

I will caveat that I'm about 5-10 hours in, and have heard lots of good things about the story, however honestly I don't really care about stories anyway unless they're unbelievable and unique. So far this feels a bit pretentious and isn't really resonating with me

Hate the autosave mechanic, derives from Dark Souls but worse and adds nothing. The map is also awful, trying to force exploration but within quite an empty, uninteresting world 
The map design is also very poor. I have spent up to an hour in several areas just trying to find stuff, leave areas or having to re-tread steps

Enemy design has very little variety and for the first 5 hours it felt like most enemies were damage sponges (although that is improving now)

TLDR:
Pros:
-Good visuals, although not amazing
-Combat does look cool at times 
-Interesting premise
-Music is good at some points and quite unique

Cons:
-Very unintuitive
-Story is hit or miss, and is heavily pushed in a very Japenese manga style, which can hugely drag pacing
-Not a fan of sexualizing the main character. Feels very creepy being able to look up your characters skirt with animations / movements built in by design

author: zelaxi
review_text: Nier: Automata is a masterclass in game design, combining thrilling hack-and-slash combat, a thought-provoking narrative, and an unforgettable soundtrack. The combat system offers a perfect blend of speed and strategy, with the ability to switch between weapon types and utilize Pod programs for endless combat possibilities. The story explores deep existential themes through complex characters like 2B, 9S, and A2, with multiple endings that enhance replayability. The post-apocalyptic world is richly detailed, creating an immersive atmosphere that complements the game's themes. The soundtrack by Keiichi Okabe perfectly captures the emotional tone, enhancing both combat and exploration. While the voice acting is sparse and some cutscenes lack visual consistency, these are minor flaws in an otherwise exceptional experience. Nier: Automata challenges, inspires, and leaves a lasting impression, offering a unique and rewarding journey.

author: theBobOfBobs
review_text: I wont even begin to try to understand why japanese gamedev is like this. This is just sad.

author: lastfox
review_text: The presentation and art design are the only things that are beyond average. And I still have no clue why all the androids are dressed as gothic lolitas. It doesn't fit with the serious themes which are going deep into Neon Genesis Evangelion fanfic territory. A'other one of those open world games which is a giant elobarate fetch quest. None of the items or weapons give you a game-changing experience. Instead the Rpg elements are too rudimentary implemented, they barely affect the game. And that several side quests are blocked without further notice or option going back, unless with the next character is frustrating. Especially since certain side quest have to be unlocked on route A first. That is my whole experience in a nutshell: tedious and frustrating. Even traveling on the back of an animal feels boring. I went through the whole ordeal and finished the game with all three characters and the first ending was by far the best one. The other two added a twist and meta modernist ramblings, but I honestly didn't care since all the characters are cold and unlikeable. The game never even gives you a choice to save X but give up Y like in the Witcher 3. There's no interactive storytelling with the 26 endings, just forced cinematics to one end that is worse than the other. Also the forced themes and parallels to our society were really tired. This game wants to be super artsy and deep but at the same time throws the most stereotypical anime clichés at the player, every occasion it gets. I want my 10 hours of gameplay back and wished I would have read a good novel instead. Make no mistake this isn't a game that gives you chills, an experience or good vibes, it's just a product to waste your time on meaningless quests that have no effect on the story.

author: Rgm191
review_text:
Storia e narrazione molto convincente .
Molto intuitivo capire cosa bisogna fare, fin dai primi minuti di gioco. 
Le movenze del gatto sono un qualcosa di unico . Molto bello il rapporto tra il gatto e i Robot che incontra , sopratutto la sua mascotte che spesso risulta indispensabile per progredire nella storia. Molto bella l’idea di creare una lingua incomprensibile , ma grazie al traduttore è tutto molto comprensibile anche in italiano . Saltare sui tetti , per capire come raggiungere alcuni luoghi , alla ricerca di oggetti o aiuti non risulta noioso. il suono e le ambientazioni sono ben curate ed esplorare è sempre un piacere sia per gli occhi che per la mente . Capire cosa fare risulta semplice , farlo , delle volte necessita ingegno ed investigazione , anche se non troppo difficile. Molto belle anche le situazionid’azione , dove bisogna correre , saltare e successivamente anche eliminare i nemici con un’arma costruita dagli amici robot. 
Un gioco come questo mi ha piacevolmente lasciato sorpreso. 
Giocato su un Mac mini M2pro al massimodella qualità grafica a1920 x 1080 sempre fluido . 
Purtroppo in un solo caso il gioco si è bloccato. 
Consiglio a tutti coloro che amano esplorare , ragionare e vivere una storia ben narrata , ma che odino quel genere di giochi dove bisogna spesso sparare. Finalmente un gioco che si discosta dal solito genere spara salta e corri.

review_text: Stray is a good game that ends too quick IMO 8 hour run time is NOT enough for the price point at the time of my review ($30) hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, environments, and story will keep you engaged and craving more

author: srdnl
review_text: The game is pretty short, but that’s actually a good thing — it doesn’t get boring. The story is simple and short, but still interesting. You want to see what happens next, even if some parts are predictable. There are also a few side quests, like collecting things or helping someone. There aren’t too many of them, so they don’t get annoying. The atmosphere is amazing — 10 out of 10. The soundtrack is great too. The graphics are nice and pleasant. The gameplay is fun, and it’s especially enjoyable just walking around as a cat in these beautiful locations. The puzzles aren’t hard, but sometimes you can end up stuck somewhere with no easy way **** ending was really sad. This is the first game that actually made me tear up at the end. I definitely recommend trying it, but it’s a good idea to watch a review first — in case puzzles and adventures in an underground neon-lit city full of robots aren’t your thing.(not my translate)

author: Samvell
review_text:
Probably a good game if you just wanna turn off your brain and vibe, but the game has nothing else to offer. There's close to no gameplay. You just **** around the environments the whole game. I'd say the game has a nice, relaxed atmosphere to it, but vibes can only carry the game so far.
The graphics are definitely nice. Yes, it's 2015 level graphics, but the overall art direction is great. Except for the cats themselves, which often trigger that uncanny valley feeling in the cutscenes. The music is sparse and amorphous. For the most part it felt very unintrusive, and intentionally so. I'd say it fits the game well, although there's a slim chance I'll ever wanna hear it outside of the game. I have to note though that some musical cues felt off at times. For example, there was this one time when I was just walking down an alley and this really intense "action" music started playing for some reason, even though there was no action going on in the game at the moment whatsoever.
The game design felt inconsistent. A lot of the objects are climbable, while others that look exactly the same aren't for some reason.
I wasn't a fan of the scripted events either. There is one early on in the game where you have to run from zurks and I failed it like four times in a row. Why? Because the moment you have to jump off the ledge you can't  press W+Space, you have to press just Space, unlike the rest of the game where W+Space works just fine. It's little inconsistencies like these that really ruin the enjoyment and leave a bitter taste in my mouth.
Overall, this is a pretty great sci-fi cat simulator. If you like cats and don't like thinking, I'd say this game is definitely for you. Me though, I couldn't help but feel utterly bored.

author: Sepherim
review_text: Stray es un juego con un potencial que no alcanza. La base de todo es la fantasía de jugar como un gato, pero al final más que hacer eso lo que tienes es un walking simulator donde el personaje es un gato pero mucho de lo que haces no es lo que haría un gato. Añade al walking simulator algo de diálogo para crear una historia super básica y genérica, algunos puzzles tan sencillos que llamarlos puzzles es una exageración y algunas secciones un poco más ágiles y más o menos tienes el juego. Lo que quedaría es la parte de exploración para encontrar objetos ocultos y así pero esa parte en general es floja, siendo las zonas muy pequeñas en su mayoría.Gráficamente el juego está bastante bien ejecutado, especialmente el gato está fantástico, pero a mi a nivel estético me acabó cansando mucho. El sonido es más bien flojo, con unos efectos escasos y repetitivos, y una música poco presente y que en general mejor sin ella. Y el juego tiene importantes bugs, causando reinicios de ordenador e incluso llegué a un punto en que hay que hablar con un PNJ y no quería, siendo imposible avanzar en el juego y me dio demasiada pereza volver a empezarlo (probé a reempezar el capítulo y mismo problema) así que no pude acabarlo y eso que es un juego muy corto (tiene un logro para hacerlo en menos de 2 **** resultado, en mi opinión, es una oportunidad perdida. Un 4.

author: Broyax
review_text:
Oh qu’il est mignon le minou ! et rare en plus… parce qu’un rouquin tigré comme ça, j’en ai jamais vu… mais le voici perdu dans une ville abandonnée… mais qui peut devenir hostile, car elle n’est pas abandonnée par tout le monde ou plutôt par tous ces bidules ici et là !Lesquels vous sautent dessus… et là, c’est le drame ! et du coup, ils ont gâché leur gentil simulateur de promenade, c’est ballot quand même… ils l’ont gâché avec ces saloperies et en même temps des sortes d’énigmes pour s’en sortir, je **** qui somnolais gentiment devant ce truc assez dépaysant, ma foi -et fort joliment fait en plus. La patte artistique est là, servie par une technique pas mal du tout en fait. 

Moi qui somnolais à moitié donc, car le simulateur de promenade est propice à la somnolence, forcément. Et voilà qu’ils me font chier avec leurs peluches enragées qui sautent et tuent mon chat !!Et là, c’est le drame ! désinstallation immédiate et note-sanction en guise de punition (et inversement). Mais j’irai jusqu’à deux quand même, oui deux points, car il ne faut point être trop sévère non plus. Quand même. Ils ont tout gâché, la promenade est foutue, retour à la maison, mon chaton !

author: Gyan_fg
review_text:
Los de Valve siempre han sido y seran los mejores en hacer secuelas, esta no es la excepcion, es una obra maestra en: personajes, diseño de niveles, lore, humor; y esto incluye los dialogos, acciones y desciciones de los personajes, las voces me encantan tanto en español como en ingles.


SPOILER ALERT


Que Wheatley se vuelva malo pero es muy estupido y vuelva todo mierda, y tenemos que hacer una tregua con GlaDOS que nos termina uniendo mas y descubrimos que ella era la esposa del fundador de aperture, y todo lo que descubrimos de los origenes de aperture y los portales y nos transporta a una epoca mas antigua de todo. Despues de derrotar a Wheatly y al final le cedemos el control a GlaDOS y nos termina salvando de quedar en el espacio, y al final GlaDOS tiene su redencion, y al final Wheatly tambien tiene su redencion, y que GlaDOS elimine a Caroline de su mente o algo asi, porque al final GlaDOS es GlaDOS y ella es perfecta y tiene sentimientos y es mas humana que muchos personajes de otros videojuegos. ES SIMPLEMENTE **** una obra maestra en todos los sentidos, no falla tecnicamente en nada, simplemente juegalo para verlo y comprobarlo todo tu mismo, habia veces que cargaba partida a proposito solo para volver a escuchar los dialogos de los personajes, que putisima obra **** probe el modo cooperativo pero de seguro que tambien es una obra maestra.

TE AMO PORTAL 2
TE AMO, ESTA VEZ, GLADOS
TE AMO VALVE
SIEMPRE INNOVANDO
SIEMPRE HACIÉNDOME FELIZ
Y SIEMPRE
ADELANTADO A SU ÉPOCA.

В принципе, в игре можно залипнуть, и это наверное первая игра, в жанре выживание, которая мне понравилась. В игре даже сюжет есть, который можно пройти в "особом" режиме, который сложнее, чем вся игра. В общем, она точно заслуживает внимания.

author: Broyax
review_text:
C'est l'été, c'est la saison des étrons indés ! cependant, il n'y a point de véritable saison en ce qui con-cerne les étrons indés, seulement des périodes éventuelles de recrudescence parce que la saison des étrons indés, c'est toute l'année !

Ainsi, ce "Don't Starve" (ne crève pas de faim...) est un très indigne représentant de l'indignité des étrons indés dans son genre, lui et ses graphismes innommables en 16 couleurs... ou 50 nuances de marron ! marron clair, marron foncé, marron moyen, marron médian, marron plus clair... c'est pour repeindre les chiottes, je suppose ?. Ou serait-ce parce que le petit personnage gogolo a la chiasse à force de bouffer de la merde ?

D'ailleurs, à propos de bouffer, il faut vraiment crever la dalle pour jouer à un tel sous-produit, bête, très con et très répétitif dans ses mécaniques recyclées de survie à la mords-moi-le-noeud. Aussitôt commencé, on veut déjà le quitter parce qu'il nous fait déjà chier. Bref, don't play this pile of **** !

author: UncleEd
review_text:
Tedious game with a beautiful make-up. Don’t Starve is one of the more popular indie games of the recent years for reasons I simply do not understand. It does look charming indeed. In fact, it has beautiful Tim Burtonesque style graphics and the game easily grabs the attention of anyone who takes a look at the screenshots. You start as a character whose only goal is to survive as long as possible. Similar to other survival games, you farm, craft, build to stay alive. The first problem with Don’t Starve is that the grinding part is simply boring. Often, it feels like a flash game with a fairly bad user interface where you click, click, click with your left mouse button without having any kind of fun. If you are curious about how grinding can be fun, please check Terraria out.

Second major problem with Don’t Starve is the permadeath. I am not suggesting that permadeath is bad per se, it can be quite enjoyable when it is done right. In Don’t Starve, however, it turns the tedious game design into something unbearable. You may find yourself grinding for hours, just to die by a random encounter (and it won’t be your fault). Oh yeah, some might suggest “that’s what the game is about” or “you will learn from your death”. Just give me a break… By now you should have played plenty of difficult video games to differentiate good game design from bad ones. Just look at the Souls series. When you die, you know you made a mistake. Maybe you made your move too early. Maybe you did not block the attack when you were supposed to. And if you die, you may lose your “souls” and thereby some of your progress, but not the entire game. In Don’t Starve, unless you are playing with a second monitor with wiki open, there is no way of knowing what will kill you. The only way to learn about what kills you is to be killed by it. And then you will start over, go through the tedious grind for hours and die again for another reason you could simply not prevent. In Don’t Starve, you are Sisyphus…

Last but not the least, the combat is atrocious. Combat in Don’t Starve is literally the same combat in any of the other thousands of flash games. If you have a good armor, left click the enemy until it dies. Or alternatively, make the enemy chase you and do your attacks while you are on the run.

If dull, repetitive games with poorly executed game mechanics are for you, play Don’t Starve. If you have a friend who happens to have the same tastes as you do, play Don’t Starve Together. But if it is the art style that pulls you in, your valuable time would be much better spent rewatching The Nightmare Before Christmas.

3.5/10

author: ElAticoGamer
review_text: Hollow Knight isn't just a game: it's an emotional experience disguised as entomological torture. It makes you suffer, frustrates you, humiliates you... and yet, when it's over, all you can say is, "Should I start another playthrough?" That is its power: converting pain into art.Everything in Hallownest (its silence, its difficulty, its withered beauty) is designed to make you feel something real. Every fall teaches, every victory thrills, and every note reminds you why this Metroidvania remains the gold standard of the genre. So yes: thank you, Team Cherry, for ruining my nerves... but also for healing my soul.

author: LUXOID
review_text: Hollow Knight was my first metroidvania, and I absolutely loved it. The animations are incredibly smooth, and the art style is beautiful and iconic. At first it might look like a cozy little game, but you quickly realize it’s not—it’s challenging, but never unfair. The more you play, the more satisfying it becomes, especially during the amazing boss fights. Beating them feels great every time. My favorite boss fight was the Mantis Lords one, which almost feels like a rhythm game because of how perfectly timed everything is. The developers created a deep and fascinating lore, full of mysteries waiting to be uncovered, even though the narrative itself can be a bit unclear at times—it’s not always easy to fully understand what happened in Hallownest. The map is huge and packed with secrets, and every single area is memorable. After spending several hours in the game, you start to know your way around instinctively. All the characters are wonderfully designed, each one iconic in their own way. Hollow Knight is a masterpiece of atmosphere, challenge, and exploration—an unforgettable experience.

author: awhimsicalflame
review_text:
This game changed everything.
Hollow Knight was a random exploding success, a genre definer, something every subsequent metroidvania is held up to and compared with. The gameplay loop is sleek and sharp, the map and currency systems solid, the charm builds customisable. Exploration is rewarded and there is no right way to play. The sense of wonder and dread as we explore the buried kingdom, the challenge of the bosses and the platforming, the utterly stunning world and character design, and Christopher Larkin's generational soundtrack, all come together into what I dare call the prime metroidvania. This game has held strong, the lore and horrifically tragic story keeping audiences engaged for more than half a decade, and is a prime example of how love for the craft always beats the love of cash. Gaming changed with Hollow Knight. It wasn't obvious at first, but the release of Silksong makes it all the more clear.

author: ThatoneHELP
review_text:
Omori, for a RPG made by a small dev team and being OMOCATS first game. Is probably one of the greatest if not the greatest of all time in the RPG aspect. Now the reason? The story, Besides the random negative reviews that sound like they were asleep while playing the game And writing the reviews. The games gameplay is fine, not anything groundbreaking but it is enjoyable. But the story, music and art (in cutscenes) is immaculate. It is the most deep game I have ever played, and I am confident that I will never forget this story, now I won't spoil anything because this is a game genuinely needed to be played blind. But if my word doesn't mean anything, you can search up OMORI on YouTube and you can see so many different YouTubers, big and small praising the game in thumbnails and stuff. It makes sense too.

The game has around 20 hours of gameplay and six years of real life development to flesh out everything from the story to the music and hand drawn and pixel art.

Now I get it, OMORI isn't for everyone, the game is rated M for a reason and it is not because of swearing, sex or violence (No Humphrey doesn't count), it genuinely gets that deep. And in MY summary? If you like RPG games OR like games or media with a good story, OMORI will GENUINELY be the closest you get to a MUST-PLAY (also it's worth the 20 dollars btw, crazy how pokemon legends ZA is 70 yet absolute dog **** compared to OMORI OR literally ANY other indie game.)

And key note, Omori in all is a serious game, so if you can't take it seriously, then you most likely won't enjoy it to the degree that everyone else playing the game did. Omori at its core is a STORY game. So I don't actually advise playing it if you don't like a good story, but if you do it's a near must play.

author: Anonymus97
review_text: Let’s cut through the pastel-colored fog: Omori is a confused, clunky mess that tries to be everything and ends up being nothing. It’s a Frankenstein’s monster of mismatched genres—psychological horror, quirky comedy, slice-of-life drama—all stitched together with the subtlety of a Tumblr meme dump. The tonal whiplash is real: one moment you're navigating trauma, the next you're watching a talking toaster crack jokes. It’s not clever—it’s **** controls are stiff and outdated, a relic of RPG Maker’s limitations. Movement feels sluggish, menus are unintuitive, and the interface design is more aesthetic than functional. It’s like the developers prioritized mood boards over playability.Combat? A snoozefest. The emotion system is a neat idea on paper, but in practice it’s shallow and repetitive. Battles drag on with little strategic depth, and the pacing is glacial. You’ll spend more time mashing attack than actually thinking. Compared to other indie RPGs with tactical nuance, Omori feels like a **** characters are painfully flat. Sunny, Basil, Aubrey—none of them evolve meaningfully beyond their archetypes. They exist to serve the plot’s emotional beats, not to feel like real people. Dialogue is often stilted, and the attempts at humor land with the grace of a brick. It’s the kind of writing that might resonate with someone deep in a Tumblr echo chamber, but outside of that bubble, it’s hard to take **** let’s talk about the reviews. The praise surrounding Omori is almost cult-like, centered almost exclusively on its “sad story.” But that’s the bait. The game leans heavily on trauma and tragedy to mask its mechanical shortcomings. It’s emotional manipulation dressed up as profundity. Critics and fans alike seem so enamored with the ending’s gut punch that they ignore the slog it takes to get there.

author: Womly
review_text: Played a bunch more games over the past week or so, so imma write a bit about themPlayed “before your eyes” at toms cus he has vr n whatnotAll I had going into this is the selling point of the blink mechanic and the fact it might make me cry, so I didn’t really know what to ****’s hard to describe anything about the game without spoiling it so I’ll say this; the way the mechanic of blinking pushing forward time is really innovative and clever, works amazingly in VR. It’s about the POV / life **** who grows older and you see his life unfold. The start of the game you’re greeted with a ferryman who wants to hear about your life and then it’s shown blah blah, there’s some twists and turns at some point in the game yadda… basically the way the story is executed and reveals is so clever and I think the medium of vr with this blink mechanic drives the emotion home because, with blinking enabled, you forcefully don’t want to miss anything important, you wana not accidentally blink and miss out on a chunk of the story. I think playing the game with it enabled works well (I was advised to turn the mechanic off but I think it worked better having that experience). Metaphorically the “blink and you’ll miss it” idea is neat, for a story driven game you don’t wana miss out on a chunk of the person’s life or story and you don’t know what’ll happen next in their life. It’s an interesting and very emotional game, from the segments with the ferryman to the sound design, writing and voice acting it’s all ace and very emotional not only at the end, but just throughout as it throws around many heartbreaking moments so well, the littlest things are so sad to hear.Great short game and I get the hype for it. Only issue I had wasn’t the game itself but just the vr being uncomfortable on my head after a while-9/10

author: NikoWright06
review_text:
I played this game on my phone on a flight from Greece to NY. I just wanted to pass time as it’s a lengthy flight (10 hours)—
There had never been a game that has hit as hard as this one. It’s probably the shortest story game I have played but is the most beautiful story I have ever seen in gaming (and by far the most sad)
Everyone should play this game fr(free on netflix gaming on your phone)

-When I played the game I really appreciated the artwork and choices you make.
The plot twist near the end of the game hits SO HARD and it’s so tragic-Don’t wanna spoil

The last scene of the game is one of the most gut wrenching and beautiful moments I’ve ever encountered in a video game 

This is perf storytelling

author: CadetKidd
review_text: What a surprise this game has been for me. This is the first speedrunning game I've ever played, and it was a great experience. I enjoy fast-paced FPS games like Doom, and now I can say I enjoy games like Neon White, even though it's not a **** is a puzzle game—a puzzle game with story and shooting elements injected—and it works like a charm. I typically don't like the Japanese aesthetic in games, but this one didn't bother me in that sense. The characters, though, are simply put: "lame." They have weird reactions, and their personalities are too simple. The story is also super **** could have been better if they had included more boss fights. But this is definitely worth trying because, from the start, you'll know that you are playing something original.

author: filip6666
review_text:
It's amazing gameplay-wise but one thing made me so mad I can't go higher than 7.
The fact that menuing is so slow, you can't quickly reset, you can't skip dialogues, cutscenes, that giving out presents takes ages is mind boggling. 
The characters and story are very cringe and you really don't want to listen to anything they have to say, but it seems the creators were so proud of this cringefest they force players to bear through it. 
There's a lot style over substance here, which I could let slide if the substance was noteworthy, but unfortunately it's nauseating.

Ancak bir süre sonra hep aynı şeyleri yapma hissi oyundan soğutuyor. Ayrıca hikâyesi de oyuncuyu içine çekmekte pek başarılı değil.

review_text:
+ High fast-paced gameplay
Every level is a speedrunning puzzle. level design is wel done & really leans into it.

+ Forces you to strive for excellence
If your like me you'll play most stages multiple times to improve your run and shave of seconds of your time. 
Title music f●●●ing slaps

– Characters are cringy (on purpose?)
Expect anime tropes, edge-lord banter and some painful dialogue. sometimes it works most of the time it's cringy.

~ Story is serviceable

It's better than the cringy characters and dialouge. and it's not a super long game and the story moves allong.

review_text: Life Is Strange is a game about what happens when you give supernatural powers to a teenager who still has a childish mindset and who must face all the difficulties of life. This game is almost perfect, the plot is incredibly engaging, I was constantly walking around and talking to people, so it's really interesting. I didn't notice much of a difference in the remastered version, so I downgraded it due to the huge overpayment. Overall, both the original and the remastered version are the best games in their genre. I recommend it to everyone, and it's best to buy the remastered version when it's on sale :)

author: Ladyblack89
review_text:
Cosa sei disposto/a a fare per salvare qualcuno? 

LIS è stato amore a prima vista. Giocato in età adulta,  si comprendono meglio tante cose. Da amante delle avventure grafiche, non potevo farmelo sfuggire e, devo dire, sono rimasta rapita da questo gioco. Non il migliore tecnicamente e con qualche errore di sceneggiatura ma la storia è incalzante, i **** son tutti ben scritti e il mistero si mixa perfettamente col resto. Hai subito voglia di capire cosa succederà e come andrà a finire. Le musiche poi sono bellissime e, oramai, iconiche, i colori e gli effetti pittorici davvero ispirati ed enigmi carini e divertenti. Amerete Chloe e Max. In ultimo, un plauso ai ragazzi di Dontnod per le scelte richieste nel gioco. Alcune anche molto difficili ma tanto apprezzate. Un ottimo gioco, davvero. Da giocare per arricchirsi un bel po'.

author: Salqun
review_text: It truly changed my life. I don't even know why I gave it a try, I was only playing multiplayer games at the time and had just downloaded it because I got it for free. But it turned out to be one of, if not my favorite game. Its only downside is that sometimes you could theoretically use your power but the game doesn't let you do that, just for the sake of not solving everything with your powers and for the story to be able to happen. Everything else is perfect: the lovable and hateable characters, the intriguing story, surprising plot twists, amazing soundtrack, and awesome art style. This game won't leave you indifferent for better or worse.

author: kunartz
review_text: Life is Strange es un título que siempre había querido jugar, pero que terminó siendo una experiencia completamente olvidable. Debo reconocer que la historia está muy bien construida en la mayor parte del juego… hasta llegar a los finales. Y, por dios, ¿qué son esos finales en comparación con todo lo anterior? Se sienten apresurados, dejan demasiados cabos sueltos y dan la impresión de que lo único importante es lo que ocurre entre las dos protagonistas, mientras que el resto de los personajes simplemente no importan.Esto me lleva a otro punto: hay demasiadas interacciones con secundarios que, al final, no tienen peso en la trama. En cada capítulo apenas reaparecen con una interacción mínima, y honestamente, para eso mejor no haberlos incluido y evitar hacernos perder tiempo en diálogos que no aportan nada.A lo anterior se suma la música, que deja bastante que desear, y los escenarios, que resultan decepcionantes. Juegos de principios de los 2000 parecen haber puesto más cariño en sus paisajes y fondos que lo que aquí se muestra.

author: apeot2002
review_text:
Life is Strange: True Colors reclaims the franchise’s strength, but its weaknesses, too.

First off, I need to declare my bias: I regard the original Life is Strange as one of the best, most memorable gaming experiences in my life. I liked the prequel “Before the Storm” well enough, mostly because it gave me more of one of my favorite characters. Life is Strange 2, however, left me cold.

So when I say that True Colors felt like a return to form for me, that is high praise. This slice of life story around another teen with with supernatural abilities (supernatural empathy instead of time manipulation) making their home in a small community inhabited by quirky, well realized character (Colorado mining town instead of Oregon coastal village) is just as engrossing, charming and gripping as the tale of Chloe and Max was.

Alex Chen, an orphan grown up in the system and our protagonist, has had a hard life, but things are looking up for her. Upon invitation by her estranged but loving brother, she moves to the small mining town of Haven Springs, and right then and there the game won me over: This very first scene is incredibly bucolic, full of life, color and golden sunlight. You can practically smell the fresh mountain air. That was the first hook that got me.

The second hit home only minutes after, when I witnessed the awkward reunion between Alex and her brother. Both of them didn’t quite know how to deal with each other and the situation, and I could read every conflicting emotion, not only in the excellent voice performances, but in their expressions and body language, too, and it all felt so true, so emotionally resonant that I couldn’t help falling in love with these two lovable, damaged humans trying clumsily to connect to each other, the captured facial animations were that good. 

These two things, colorful, joyful art direction and charming, emotionally resonant characters are the great strengths of this game, and they made playing through it a joy. Together, they convincingly create the idyllic atmosphere of a tight-knit community living in the ideal small town. Or would, if the actual plot didn’t complicate things. There is actually quite a bit of socio-political commentary to be found, if you’re open for that kind of thing.

The plot itself meanders a bit at times, but still creates room for a few incredibly moving scenes, the odd successful twist and ultimately a finale that for all its understated subtlety packs an incredible punch. Unfortunately there are a few mediocre valleys between these peaks of engagement, and a lot of them have to do with the implementation of Alex’s superpower. While the idea of Super Empathy is fascinating and is used very well during the high points of the narrative, Deck Nine struggled to create meaningful everyday applications of it. But they couldn’t let it lie either, thus Alex has to empath her way through way too many two sentence dialog sequences with no import and no emotional resonance.

As a controller-based adventure game, there are few gameplay systems to be had, and the riddles here barely deserve the name. There are precious few things to be discovered away from the beaten path. Innovation is scarce, after you’re over the incredibly improved character animations. If you are not here for the characters, the vibes and the story, you might not have a good time.

But if you are, if you want to see Alex through her journey, smile with her, commiserate with her tears, you will find it incredibly easy to fall in love with her, and with Haven Springs. 

TLDR: True Colors is a return to form for the Life is Strange franchise. While it might be just one step above a walking simulator, this game will nevertheless charm you with its characters and atmosphere.

author: dreamcatcher8

author: Ciocolici
review_text:
Life is Strange: True Colors, a game I've been eagerly anticipating, truly lived up to my expectations. As a long-time fan of LiS, I was curious to see how Deck Nine would handle this installment, given their previous work on Before the Storm, which, while decent, was just a prequel with an existing storyline. However, True Colors presented a completely original tale from start to finish, and boy, did they deliver excellently.

The gameplay remains familiar, but with intriguing new features and gameplay elements tied to the protagonist's unique power, adding a fresh twist. The choices I made felt relevant, and I relished the various options I had throughout the game. The graphics are generally fantastic, but there was one gripe that broke my immersion - witnessing sudden changes in texture quality when new objects or scenes appeared. Additionally, there were occasional instances of unexpected FPS drops that lingered for entire scenes, albeit these were rare occurrences, happening maybe three or four times in the entire game. Despite these minor issues, I must commend the breathtaking scenery and the phenomenal OST. The soundtrack, in particular, was truly outstanding, capturing that classic LiS essence. The visuals might not reach the level of DontNod's previous works, but they were still stunning, and the facial animations were incredibly impressive, surpassing my expectations even after seeing them in the trailers. Can you believe it's still LiS?

Now, onto the heart of it - this game screams Life is Strange through and through. It radiates more LiS vibes than LiS 2 ever did, and Alex, the main character, is simply the cutest, most lovable character the series has seen so far. The supporting cast is equally well-crafted and captivating. While it may not have outdone the brilliance of the first LiS, I found myself emotionally invested in Alex's story right from the first chapter (now chapters instead of episodes). Her heartrending backstory evokes empathy early on, which is a definite plus. I did sense that Life is Strange and LiS 2 were more expansive in some ways - not just gameplay or story-wise, but in terms of the world they built. True Colors felt somewhat smaller in comparison, though I still adored the story and its universe and couldn't help but make some comparisons throughout my playthrough. There were moments where I felt the final episode could have been handled better, though it wasn't bad by any means; it just had room for improvement in certain aspects, in my opinion.

In conclusion, I absolutely loved Life is Strange: True Colors. It successfully encompassed everything that makes LiS special - it was great, melancholic, intense, and captivating all at once. It captured those emotional highs and lows I've come to associate with the series, leaving me thoroughly engrossed in the story. While I personally enjoyed it more than LiS 2, it still couldn't dethrone the original LiS from its throne (no comparison with BtS or Captain, as that wouldn't be fair). More LiS games, please! I can't get enough of this world, and I eagerly await any new installments that may come our way.

author: AgentLvi
review_text: Great game. The story is decent. The scoring is great, visual is really amazing, the voice & sound is also amazing

Amazing storytelling game. Please produce more games like this!! I only wish there was an options setting to make the interactive objects less noticable (i.e. make those white borders disappear) so that the world looks more natural and discovering those items would be more rewarding.

author: eyyoemrecan
review_text: As someone who has played and liked all of the Life Is Strange series, I really liked this game, and it is one of the best games for me in the series.

author: KinimodYunmi
review_text:
Dieser Teil zerreißt einen emotional leider nicht so extrem bzw. überhaupt als in Life is Strange und Life is Strange Before the Storm. Auch die "holy ****" Momente, die es zumindest noch in Life is Strange 2 gab, gibt es nicht mehr. Man hat leider auch das Gefühl, dass jede Entscheidung recht egal ist, da es in normalen Dialogen kaum was ausmacht und die EINE "große Entscheidung" der Episode ist jetzt auch nichts weltbewegendes, die Story geht trotzdem ihren Weg, man kann dadurch nichts verhindern. Wenn man sich die Entscheidungen, wie üblich am Ende einer jeden Episode durchließt, merkt man das. Man hat lediglich die Wahl einer Person was zu erzählen oder nicht. Das juckt die Story aber nicht die Bohne, bis auf an einer Stelle, die aber auch total optional ist, danach setz die feste, unabänderbare Story wieder ein.

Es ist kein klassisches LiS, wie wir es gewohnt sind. Die schockierenden Momente, in denen man sich denkt, oh nein, das darf doch nicht wahr sein gibt es nicht, man wird emotional nur sehr gering mitgenommen und die zwei Stellen mit einer, ich sag mal Offenbarung von der Story des Spiels her, kann man sich sogar denken. Hier wurde sich darauf fokussiert mehr Gameplay einzubauen, anstatt eine extreme Story zu schreiben.

Die Story ist trotzdem schön und da ich das Spiel ein Wochenende lang genießen konnte, vor allem durch die klassische Life is Strange Musik, die immer sehr gut zur Atmosphäre gepasst hat, kann ich dem Spiel einfach keinen Daumen runter geben und freuen mich schon auf das Steph-DLC, in die ich mich auch wieder direkt verliebt habe.

author: 2spooky4me
review_text: A step up in quality in most aspects - except for where it really matters. It looks a lot more polished, but the tame story and Alex's "power" really doesn't make for a immersive experience. The story is very weak and short compared to the first game. I tried really hard to give this game a chance, but ultimately—it did not deliver.

author: immamrmax
review_text: This game failed to deliver similar LIS game experience previous games did bring me. The story looks rushed, some places I even think it was deliberately rushed. In the other LIS games you usually are given with options and choices that will affect your future, or the world around. Even though there are choices to make in this game, they don't seem too different one from another. It's like picking between two apples - one is green and the other is red: at the end of the day, it's still an apple you choose. So when you've finished the game and you're looking at the charts of other players' decisions you kinda think to yourself: so that is all there was? I almost never felt it for the characters, even during their hardest times. I suppose I didn't have enough time and opportunity to get to know them better. Then, when playing particular parts of the game, it suddenly feels like the character is a naive 12 y.o. girl. But seriously, when making some decision, Alex is being way too naive and for some reason over-simplifies some important events and decisions. The superpower itself is very interesting and is worth exploring, but we don't particularly see any development on this throughout the whole game.

author: TheButterCup
review_text: This game isn't a sequel to Life is Strange 1. It's a perfectly told new story. Those who aren't open to that will struggle. If you're open to it, the story is emotional, heartbreaking, and captivating. A very successful second part.

(I have already written a review. This is a rate for its PC version.)

Constantly changing characters, as it is a story of running away in a hurry, yet still succeeds in helping building meaningful connections with the game, maybe with its atmosphere. It is not a game to be finished at one sitting, maybe this is its drawback, it is designed to be understood in scrutiny.

author: nickinworld
review_text:
It's actually unfair for me to compare the mechanics and story of this game with the first one and conclude that "it was better in the first game" for reasons like "it's not the protagonist who has the powers" or "they don't stay still in a same place, they are always changing" because THIS IS HOW THE GAME GOES. It was meant to be different from the first one, and the plot of "you are not who has the powers this time, it's your litte brother, who you have to educate through the whole game" it's actually really interesting for me.

This game deserves an open-minded experience.

author: Imperfectionist
review_text:
Life is Strange: Babysitting Simulator   
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Oh boy I never thought I would actually be unable to push myself to play this game. It was an absolute hellish mental torture. Daniel is just one hell of piece of **** brat childish and insufferable character. It's actually insane how insufferable he is. The relationship between Sean and Daniel is more unrealistic then having super powers, like who tf even have such patience would have to be a saint and a parent of this lil **** to actually treat him as good as Sean. Like holy mother of god couldn't they just have give us the option to abandon him and end the game early. In short, Daniel just spends the entirety of LIS2 **** up Sean's life in every way imaginable, and we're supposed to be cool with it and love him anyway, because blah blah he's just a kid. Sean's a kid too, and he sure as hell doesn't deserve all this. Anyway, I **** on this game enough, I stopped playing around midway in EP3 and the good things about this game are its amazing soundtrack and how good the art style looks. That's pretty much the only good things about it. Everything else is either average or below average like the super power of moving **** around is just inferior to what we had in LiS 1 and LiS True Colors and the story is just straight up dumb, Sean's decision is dumb and makes absolutely no sense story-wise and it's basically what the whole game revolves around. Oh and literally every single important decision is not up to you, Sean will just agree to all of Daniel's braindead moronic ideas that will keep getting you in all sorts of stupid troubles just so they can keep the story going.

TL;DR If you can't stand the most annoying 10 yo in video games history don't play this game because even if you can stand him in EP1 he keeps constantly getting worse no matter what choices you've made.

author: Xalrandion
review_text:
Well... it's bad, like weak story, weak characters, weak gameplay bad.
First of all, I did play only 1 third of the game but believe me when I say that every time, I see my play time on this game I wonder if steam crashed and forgot to count 50 more hours.
First story and characters, I won't spoil anything but let's just say that you will need to strap your suspension of disbelief to a f-ing falcon 9 rocket for them to make sense. I know they’re young but when I was as young as them, I would also call most of their choices stupid, unconscious, and well... very stupid, and I I'm not that far from their age anyway. Which is even more infuriating with the game severe lack of nuance and subtility the game will always force you to choose between 2 extreme of the same solution something like "explode in rage" and "be extremely ungrateful and disrespectful" which will for all intent and purposes will have the same result. And when you couple that with the fact that the game make act the characters stupidly and think you're too drunk to notice it becomes just borderline insulting.
The gameplay is weak, but in another game like this I wouldn't even mention it because it should be carried by its writing...
I don't know what happened to the smartly written characters and charm of arcadia bay, If you wanted to get this one, just continue walking...

author: Korra13
review_text: This is a very nasty game. There is no spirit of the past parts in it. Very boring main characters, minor characters, and even more interesting than the main characters. It is very common to see the same house assets in different episodes. There is a lot of political overtones, hatred for believers, hatred for white people, hatred for everything. This is not Life is Strange. It's very funny to see how DONTNOD talks about injustice towards different people, but at the same time, they themselves deceived and ignored the protests of the voice actors of Life is Strange 2015. Many young children liked the game and they put 10, just because it is called the same as and the last part and for a bright picture. Don't be fooled. Little music, even less good music. Elections practically do not affect anything. The game has no decent morality. You may like the first and second episodes, but the next episodes are made very poorly, apparently the developers themselves were bored with creating the game. If you are white, a believer, be prepared for the game to hate and despise you.

author: buzz1213
review_text: This game is so underrated it's not even funny how underrated it is. The game starts off pretty well right away with 30 zombies that do kill you. that's why I give this game a solid eight.

author: hodjedi
review_text:
I thoroughly enjoyed the game... and VERY RARELY does a single player game grab my attention. I have played through The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct about 5 times now in attempts to save all the necessary survivors. EVERY time I have played through the game.. I have experienced different content (locations) I was not exposed to before...

I felt the AI was aptly responsive and worked very well. This is not the Left 4 Dead series... getting hit means soemthing... Stealth is somewhat required.

Sure, there could be more graphics tweaks, or coop, or pvp... but the game was just released... who knows what they may have in store later. Until then I found the game stimulating and entertaining all around. I also experienced no glitches or bugs.

At the end of the day.. this game was created for hardcore Walking Dead fans... which I am  and I love the game.

The game could be salvaged from a "marketing" standpoint quickly by releasing more meaty content for the game.. and not charging the players for it.

author: Duskspark
review_text: The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct is an enjoyable game that combines the claustrofobic feeling of being chased by walkers and the need to scavenge in a good way, but the graphics are very dated and some issues keep the experience from its prime.

author: PenetratorGod
review_text: For a 2013 game, the graphics and gameplay are very dated. Only Telltale has been able to make a good series of games related to the Walking Dead brand. Although years have passed, we still haven't seen a big budget AAA game from this brand. They ruined the game side like the TV series. If the owners of the Walking Dead brand didn't only care about making more and more money without spending money, a game close to Days Gone could have come by now. But after this hour, there's no point anymore. There are too many zombie games on the market.  They couldn't use it when they had the opportunity.

author: MKYounis
review_text: The Wolf Among Us really pulled me in from the start. I loved the gritty atmosphere and the way it mixed fairy tale characters with a dark, detective story. Playing as Bigby Wolf felt intense—every choice I made actually mattered and had real consequences. The art style was amazing, and the voice acting brought everything to life. Honestly, it’s one of those games that stays with you. If you like strong stories, you should definitely try it.

author: WillFyeField
review_text: While closer to a TV show or similar experience than an actual "video game," The Wolf Among Us has a rich and enthralling story with fantastic characters throughout. Enjoyable throughout its entire runtime, and leaves the player always wanting to find out more. Can't wait for the sequel.

author: Matteo123999
review_text: Best telltale games after twdg. What a masterpiece and can't wait for the sequel. Bigby is such an amazing character and his development is good and can be great if they do it right in the sequel. The plot twists in this game are so great and unexpected too

author: HaloBlues
review_text: God, I love this game. As tired as the concept may be for some, the idea of taking fairytale/fantasy characters and putting them into modern cities and realistic situations has always been something I dug, and it was done wonderfully here. The setting is vivid and easy to immerse yourself in, the characters are varied, likeable, and charming, the mystery is suspenseful and gripping, the choices and consequences are satisfying, and the soundtrack is brilliant. The ending has one of the cliffhangers that have haunted me most through my time in gaming, and I am both excited for and terrified of the sequel. Hopefully it lives up to the first game's quality and ties up the loose ends it needs to. (Sidenote I include with all Telltale reviews: Telltale's games often get a bad rap for having your choices not influence the story, but to me this misses the point of what they do. Variant endings are a nice bonus in games, and I enjoy them when they do pop up in Telltale's stories, but for the most part your choices aren't here to change where you go. They're there to change how you get there, who you are when you get there, and often who you get there with. They influence and change your relationships with the characters around you. The joy of replaying these games is to experience the different dialogue, the different reactions to you, the different routes you can take on the way, the different bonds you can evolve with people - not to have a wildly different ending. I think this aspect is overhated and sadly misunderstood by a lot of players, so if huge, game-changing differences are what you're looking for, I'd temper your expectations.)

author: Beautifulyinsan
review_text: Beautifully Written, Beautifully Presented. And for telltale the most Dynamic in experience, and if anything its not about branching paths with these games its about how you yourself engage with everything that will depend on what you get. and for me, the inability to not change some things is actually in the games favor, Because I would much rather have crucial points, and a focus be uncompromising. the Empathetic thoughtful and even emotion and intense writing have kept this game as the only rival to the walking dead. I just oddly wish the aggroget was higher then 80 but equally as so I see it as just, well its a perception on what is actually important in a game. For the type of game this is, its about the experience of seeing the world, seeing the position of Bigby and what happens to him, some things that you believe is more important, which again will not change everything but more or less, will change how you view everything in each subsequent play through. Your aggression and your softness, your approach to each character, it often change me, and made me feel a roller coaster depending on what I said, when I didn't keep track of what I said and whether or not this guy was gonna say the same thing anyways, I was feel the very grounded, tight and honestly intricate story that pulls no punches and containing bold plot twists. Immersive, and emotional to its absolute core, I just wish It was longer. not so short, only going 10 hours but It has no filler, just opting for you as a player to just feel everything and take your time, and feel the vibe. Brilliant game. Side by side for the Walking Dead honestly.

author: SilverOrlov
review_text: I gave this game an 8, but that's an advance. I really liked the game for its atmosphere, music, and of course the story itself. Lovecraft would have definitely liked this game: a short story about otherworldly horror. Maybe cosmic, maybe afterlife. Just the way he liked it. But for me personally, this game was on the verge of a 7 because walking around this island was very tiring, and because the dialogues required you to react quickly. I hate timed quests, timed traps, and timed dialogues, so for me it spoiled the feeling of the game a little. And the tedious walking could have been easily fixed with at least small fast-travel, like 4 benches in different corners of the island. And that's it. Because of this, I didn't really like running and looking for red frequencies first, and then running around the island again looking for these damn notes... and also hunting for different endings. Overall, it's an 8, but on a very-very fine line with a 7.

Storytelling is so good and it's actually like "Inception" It blows your mind and while playing the game you don't have to do so many things just look at the map and listen radio while walking. Besides our story(because I don't want to give whoever reads(btw I am glad you're reading this) any clue about the story) game has a good radio mechanic which is our literally only playable mechanic other than choosing our words which is at the very beginning I did not realize we can be quiet or we can choose to not talking. In the end, the game is all about the story and I literally started to play it and then finished it(yeah sometimes took a bathroom break as normal). You definitely should play it too and guys please make a good ending for us. See ya!!

author: ct-boi
review_text:
Oh, to be a teenager sneaking into a secluded island to party. If only that island wasn't haunted...
I first played this game 6 years ago — I now reached an ending I hadn't found.
Oxenfree is a uniquely dynamic enigmatic narrative game that is as complex as the player's willingness to engage. It introduces characters begging to be understood despite their confounded pasts. The game challenges players to look beyond the surface, reminding us that all carry a history that shapes their present.
Oxenfree prompts players to reflect on the control we have over our lives. It's a journey through acceptance, illustrating that acknowledging the past allows for moving forward. I love how deeply one can dig for lore in this game, even extending to an ARG. 
Playing today, I was able to reach an ending I was satisfied with as I could find the confidence in myself to be proud of the choices I made, embracing the consequences: a reflection of my growth.

author: Wrathzo
review_text: Oxenfree is a supernatural mystery/horror graphic adventure game developed and published by Night School Studio. In Oxenfree, players assume the role of the teenage girl Alex on a weekend trip to a local island. After seemingly supernatural events occur, Alex and her friends must unravel the secrets of the island.

author: Quentinho4
review_text:
(JEU)
Mitigé. C'est l'émotion que je ressens à la fin de ce jeu.Mais c'est aussi celle que j'ai ressenti dès le début. Plonger dans un monde étant l'archétype même des clichés pour adolescent ca ne me grisait pas trop au début. (ma phobie les dialogues comme dans life is strange)Or, très vite le jeu a su apporter ce côté surnaturel voire même horrifique, je commençais donc à me plonger dans l'univers... je m'attendais pas à ce que l'eau soit si froide. Une grosse déception en fin de compte cette histoire et ce jeu. On est resté trop proche du jeu pour ado-bobo et ce, malgré quelques moments sympas. Cela est peut-être lié à mes choix de dialogues (non), d'ailleurs parlons de ces choix !Quelle honte, baser son jeu sur des choix mais ne laisser au joueur que 2-3 secondes pour lire les 3 choix qui s'offrent à lui, tout en devant comprendre la quantité abondante de dialogue qu'il ingurgite depuis un moment, et sans oublier la cerise sur le gâteau : les dialogues qui continuent pendant que tu dois faire tes choix sur ceux-ci. J'espère que vous serez rapides, vous avec 2 secondes, top chrono ! Non sérieusement c'est certainement la chose la plus conne que j'aie vu dans un jeu.Ajouter encore à ça un défaut terrible pour un jeu qui veut baser son expérience sur l'histoire et les dialogues : Le "doublage" atroce. Pas du tout au niveau pour ce jeu. Aucune émotion dégagée dans les voix. Que ce soit de la tristesse, de la peur ou de la joie, tout est plat. Dommage et fatal pour **** faut encore ajouter à tout ça, des décors pas beaux, des contrôles et déplacements relevant du supplice, et une bande son qui parfois, ne colle pas du tout avec l'ambiance du jeu. Je ne sais pas si cette contradiction est voulue, mais pour moi, c'est de mauvais gout.Cependant il y a un problème... l'ambiance globale du jeu dégage quelque chose ! Malgré tout les défauts j'ai voulu finir le jeu pour profiter de l'expérience jusqu'à la fin. Je ne regrette pas, même si le début du jeu m'a bien plus conquis que tout le reste. Et je peux comprendre que les adolescents puissent être marqués par Oxenfree. Mais d'un point de vue d'un adulte de 25 ans, c'était niais. C'est donc avec une grande magnanimité que je lui accorde un 4/10.

Rotten gameplay with rotten interface.

author: Drag_n
review_text:
Ok so I was lucky to have been able to download the PC version of Oxenfree for free on an offer from Epic Games this year.
I finished the game in two days, and I enjoyed this a whole lot. The storyline was good and emotional. I like how they put everything in place and I honestly loved how the characters got flashbacks from happy moments in the past. The background music was good and it created the typical atmosphere which fitted in the game. I really liked the genre of the game, it was spooky but at the same time pretty emotional, and the best part was that everything was unexpected. Not once could I guess what would happen next, and that's what made this game more exciting. The characters were greatly designed as well and the graphics of the game was just amazing. Here and there there were a few glitches or the game froze, but that's usually normal.

For people who are suffering from loss like I have, I would definitely recommend this to you. It actually helps you deal with the pain.

I would rate this game 98/100. There were some things which were hard to figure out and there could've been some guides through the game to make it easier. The map could've also tracked the characters at the exact spot in the location so that you know where you are going and if you are taking the right paths. Other than that, I am satisfied with the gameplay experience! :)

La historia está bien, sin ser excelente y tiene una duración acertada para el tipo de juego que es, aunque no tiene gran rejugabilidad, más allá de los completistas y coleccionistas de logros. Tiene dos finales, pero da pereza volver a jugar el juego entero buscando las dos chorradas que se te pasaron en la primera partida.
Y es que el juego está bien, pero no tiene más aliciente que pulsar donde el juego te dice que pinches, tomar alguna decisión de escasa trascendencia en el resultado final del juego, y estar atento para lanzar purpurina en los puntos exactos
