review_text:
The game is solid, fun, and the format is finally fair (Idk how much is gonna last do), but Konami is giving almost no support to this game, there are almost no tournaments, no interesting new things etc.
I'm gonna say making decks and opening box is rewarding and its really not pay to win.
Also the game is very luck based being a best of 1 with no side deck, players hate this and Konami refuse to give us best of 3. Also its just not that interesting to play the OCG meta of 1 years ago because that is what the Master Duel format always is, they need to support the current TCG and OCG more instead of making more and more alternative formats that nobody likes. There are free simulators which are better than Master Duel, keep that in mind.

author: InCYnity
review_text: I'm sorry, but the people complaining on here about how other people are playing are just plain bad at the game lol. Choosing to play a bad deck will net you a bad experience, that's just how things work. The game itself is a lot of fun. Great visuals, good resource system and a lot of fun to grind mostly. Gems dry up quick and the fact it's months behind the real card game kind of ****. The  best of one format is annoying but playable and it would be really nice if they implemented a banlist to follow that, but oh well. All in all, Master Duel is a lot of fun, so don't listen to the people whining that they lost to a combo deck that took a three minute turn  because they wanted to play 57 card 1900 attacker beats. Give it an honest shot and it'll be blast!

author: Akedus
review_text:
It's YuGiOh except you don't need to spend thousands of dollars if you want to compete competitively. Crafting system and starting gems give you enough to make a viable deck to climb ranked from which, you have a steady income of gems to build more decks. Presentation and music is amazing. Just a really well done YuGiOh game.
It's honestly an 8/10 but there are too many 0/10s complaining about losing to a "broken meta deck" only to describe a janky gimmick rogue deck.

author: picox
review_text:
It still has a lot to improve in terms of the ability to interact with the opponent to finish being a multiplayer.

However it is a fun filled experience for any fan of the card game.

author: Revuc
review_text:
I have played MD until the end of December 2022. I would like to make it clear, that I am speaking from my own experience and as a player who went to Diamond 5 I want to give my opinion on the game.

Yes, it is true that the game is a good F2P, at first. Newcomers will receive a good amount of Gems and support to make a few decks of your choice, be it for casual or ranking. However, the Gems' income from playing the game alone becomes quickly inefficient. At the moment, I have stopped playing, you make 145 to 195 Gems from doing daily missions by playing in rankings or events, including logins and watching live duels. Those Gems are necessary to acquire cards. For 10 packs of 10 cards, you are guaranteed to received at least a SR, it cause 1000 Gems, plus if you have no UR the next 10 packs guarantee 1 UR. A F2P player can only acquire 1 bundle of 10 packs per week. It is true tournaments and events gives you more Gems through their own missions, but those aren't always available and you need those Gems to get those packs.

Speaking of packs, I would like to speak about the issue with them. MD announced a new selected pack with 4 new archetypes in it. So I kept my Gems from my missions, since I was interested. I accumulated over 4 000 gems. When the selected pack was released, I bought the bundle of 10 packs 4 times. The results I got was, 2 out of the 10 URs necessary to play this deck. The biggest issue I have is that they aren't doing a specific pack like they did with previous archetype on release date and even if they did, I still need to buy 10 packs or craft a SR or UR card of that specific archetype just to have access to that archetype pack and said pack will be only available for 24 hours, regardless if the client is down or not.

The material system of MD works as the following; you have a card you don't need, you have the option to destroy this card and create 10 materials equals to this card's rarity and quality. For example; if I destroy 1 UR non-foil I get 10 UR materials, if it was foil = 15 UR and rainbow foil = 30 UR. From those materials, you need 30 to create a card from the same rarity then those materials; so 30 UR to get 1 UR cards. Which mean, if I don't buy many random packs and get multiple URs and SRs I don't need I'll never get those more difficult URs to get. Also, I couldn't destroy more URs, because some of them are classified as Legacy, which you can't destroy even if you have extras of. Plus, it's not possible to try out a deck before using your resources on, the only exception is if they are available on Story Mode, but they restrict what you can play in the structure deck.

My biggest complaint in the gameplay is the absurd amount of time to play a turn. I had to wait 6 to 8 minutes to play my turn, or when my opponent takes 3 to 4 minutes to decide to play that  face-down Called by the Grave. I should not wait so, so, so long to play my turn and my cards. The turn should be restrict to five minutes or a penalty for inactivity of 20 to 30 seconds, punishing those who make the decks and immediately play them without taking the time to read their effects.

The ranking system is flawed. You can only climb the ranks. This is an issue, since you are stuck on the rank you have climb to and there's no penalty to lose multiple matches. Which mean, if you are at Platinum, but your deck isn't strong enough to defeat anyone, you are stuck at Platinum until the end of that season making duel experience miserable. The ranking should work around the experience of the players and not the amount of duels they have won in a row. Free to play isn't an option, since it is completely random and the only way for me to know the level of the opponent I'm getting in is through the brief description of the room.

As for those other ways to duels, with the exception to ranks and events, they are useless. You can't get Gems except those two modes. Unless you are playing with a friend in free duels, there's no need to play Free, Story or multiplayer if you want your daily Gems. Also, forget to surrender if you have to go and still manage to pull off the mission during your rank duel, because you need to either win or lose the duel to complete your mission.

Since decks can be difficult to make because of the limited resources, events are hard to complete since those are characteristic specific. Making your duels boring and difficult, since the other option, rent decks, are terrible.

Finally, I spent a large amount of money in the hopes to get more decks and further the ranks, however my attempt was futile since I buying so much gave me nothing in return. Not even enough to get the cards I wished to craft. If the situation was in real life, I would have at least have the possibility to sell the unwanted cards to get a bit of my money back.

Yes, this game is F2P, but don't do the same mistake I made. Don't spent for a possibility.

Thank you for your time and have a good day.

author: Giovanilevin
review_text:
First thing first i'm a beginer, i never played this game in any form before... basically i'm a complete noob and my comment is a bit long but it's just my honest opinion x)

For me there are 2 obvious problems in this "game" that popped real quick :
1- the mentality of the players...
It is clear that many of them have nothing against those who play differently and remain fairplay.
However, the vast majority of comments I have read were at best disrespectful at worst insulting to anyone who didn't play like them, be it users of old decks, new ones or blockers.
2- Considering the glaring differences between the old fast decks and the new slow ones, there should be the possibility to choose between the 2 game's modes.

For me a good game is a game that gives everyone a chance to play in their own way, to find a playstyle that suit them, not a game that seems to offer several archetypes to finally just impose one or two.
Balance issues in PvP games are everywhere but this is the first time I see something like this or at least feel this way.

I dont care about wining or loosing, what i want is to have fun while playing/learning something that is new to me.
So now I have 3 choices :
- I stop,
- I build a floodgate deck since these meta decks really don't interest me,
- i forfeit everytime i end up against one of those decks (wich seeems a bit unrealistic since the vast majority is made of them).

The worst thing is that feeling of copy/paste between my opponents, i swear i checked their names just to be sure it wasn't the same player --'
Right now i'm still searching the fun factor in this game.

author: Fidolex
review_text:
KOMONEY DESTROYING THEIR OWN GAME!, this game turned into a lucky pay to win game. no strategy at all. coin flip simulator, you going first, 85% of victory. The algorith is TR4SH! so terrible that it trolls you, no kidding. boring and repetitive game, you duel against the same decks over and over again, and it will get worst, thats why they have lost over 70% of players, shame on you komoney
Edit: after almost 1 year, is the same terrible game, now we have a ftk meta deck in the ranked games...

author: Vinicius1993
review_text:
A KONAMI simplesmente não liga para as suas franquias.
O card game é e sempre será divertido, porém já faz tempo que a Konami não faz um game a altura.
Resumindo, para um jogo lançado em 2022, parece que tudo foi feito com pressa e apenas para cumprir tabela.
Não me leve a mal, mas toda a diversão que você vai ter nesse game é proveniente do próprio card game, e não do jogo "MASTER DUEL", que poderia fazer MUITO mais do que fez.
O modo solo é simplesmente esquecível.
Se você esperava alguma atenção para modos de jogo não competitivos, esqueça, o jogo simplesmente não te recompensa se você não buscar o competitivo.

E pior, o competitivo também é largado, com uma ranqueada sem novidades ou recompensas relevantes, eventos feitos esporadicamente e também sem um sistema de recompensa legal.

O jogo também te trava de várias formas claramente artificiais, pra não te dar recompensas. Exemplos: pacote de cartas legado (recompensa pelos duelos ranqueados), só te dão 2 cartas por pacote, além de dar cartas irrelevantes e que não podem virar recurso pra fazer novas cartas; gema pela subida de nível na ranqueada (uma das melhores formas de juntar gemas, mas, a cada nova season você não vai voltar da ranqueada do zero, isso pra te travar de obter recursos de subida de nível) e por ai vai.
No geral, você começa sendo bombardeado de recursos, mas depois o negócio simplesmente desanda de uma maneira que estraga a experiência, parece que o jogo não quer mais que você jogue.

Enfim, a KONAMI deveria ter vergonha na cara e fazer um game realmente relevante para o formato, que merece cada centavo do investimento que eles não fazem.

author: invokersef
review_text:
The game (digital or in paper) is frustrating and not fun.
Basically you need to go first and play a broken deck that you are supposed to copy card to card, just to have a chance of winning. Anyone can go first and checkmate the opponent even before they had a chance to play.
The days when we used to brew decks and have fun are long gone by the money hungry machine of Konami, The current game is a soulless shell that being kept and used by a company that only cares about money.
Yu-Gi-Oh was my first card game, fortunately there many other card games that have learned from the creator of Yu-Gi-Oh the true meaning behind card games

author: Shimmeywill
review_text: A great value for fun with friends. A little finicky and glitchy at times but otherwise a good time.

author: Tilt1k
review_text: Very nice way to play table games with friends online if you cant be together in one room. I would give it higher ranking if most games werent monetised. Still best way to play tabletop online.

author: DaniloElMystico
review_text: Good chance to play boardgames with friends (or without they) if you don't like leave your home

author: TatsMcGee
review_text:
Tabletop Simulator 2

What is the genre?

Its less **** and more of Physics-Engine.

Are there any similar games or is it a sequel?

It's like Garys Mod or something along those lines. Its a not in its self but its a Physics Engine that allows the users to play any game that they want.

How is the gameplay?

As I said before, it gives options to allow users or players to play any game. Specifically any card, board or tabletop game. Tabletop Simulator comes with a few basic games but where the application truly excels is in the  Steam Workshop where there are thousands of games. It's a great way to try new games before spending $70-80.

How is the offline and online?

It includes both, I have yet to play online with other people but I have played locally and it works very well.

Is there any single player?

Of course, you can. You can download Mods that have single player. You can also create your own games. The nice thing is, its a great way to playtest a new game that you're working on.

Would I recommend it?

Absolutely, I keep trying to get my friends to get the game. We used to get together and play Tabletop games every Sunday but then one of my closest friends moved away. Now obviously don't get together to play tabletop games, I keep telling them that this is a fantastic alternative.

Recap: The Good

The possibilities with this are endless.

The perfect way to create a new Tabletop Game

Recap: The Bad

It's not much ****

Recap: The Okay

N/A

author: Dirc
review_text: Fantastic narrative driven deckbuilder RPG with roguelike elements. Very smoothe and polished. Great art and character design. Very good writing. Love this game!

author: CompleteIdiot
review_text: A good deck builder needs good variety. This is where Griftlands falls short, core gameplay is simply unsatisfying long term and gets stale too quickly. Slay the Spire or Monster Train are much more engaging in this element. The main thing Griftlands does get right is the story elements. The heists are and jobs are rather engaging and there is some variety that makes you want to do at least one more run. But once I had the perfect genocide and pacifist runs, I lost all interest in rerunning the game.

author: Kdd97
review_text:
A seriously complex and interesting game. Each playthrough takes between 2-4 hours (depending on how much side content you decide to do), and each of the 3 characters has easily 2-3 playthroughs worth of differentiated storyline to choose from. The game is well written and fun to play once you get the hang of it.

Theres a fairly steep learning curve; I don't think I would recommend the game for someone who hadn't played something more simplistic like Slay The Spire (not that the games are that similar, but if this is your first deck builder you may find yourself a bit lost early on).

author: MortalisUmbra
review_text: This one and Trial of Fire are the best deck builder roguelike games I ever played...

author: YusufBolluk
review_text: Hikayeyi sallamadım ama parkur aktı. Müzikler ve görsellikte güzel. Zorlu saf parkur oyunu arıyorsanız kaçmaz.

author: egeiscimen
review_text: Emotionally resonant and mechanically tight, but the punishing difficulty curve sometimes overshadows its narrative heart.

author: SydO5
review_text: Très bon jeu de plates-formes avec un style graphique particulier mais tellement réussi. Bonne histoire, différentes ambiances mais surtout des musiques incroyables. Mécaniques de saut satisfaisantes et speedrun intéressant.

author: Boysle
review_text: Celeste features some of the most fluid and responsive movement mechanics I’ve ever experienced in a platformer. The game's design encourages mastery through repetition, and as you grow more familiar with its simple yet nuanced controls, every challenge becomes a deeply rewarding test of skill. The more you play, the more satisfying it becomes, turning difficult obstacles into moments of triumph through precision and perseverance.

author: brunonp_
review_text: Me encantó. Amo los juegos de plataformas y "run and go". A la noche cuando quería dormir, cerraba los ojos e imaginaba bosses inexistentes, totalmente enfermo me dejó el videojuego. Le cambié los controles. La barra espaciadora la usé para saltar (como en cualquier juego) y la tecla "D" para hacer el dash porque sino era incomodo como venían.

author: eMTG
review_text: What is there to say about this game that hasn't already been said. The charming artstyle, the incredible music (seriously, I listen to it during my day to day life), the fun gameplay and the unique bosses all make this game a must have for anyone with a device that can run it. Haven't played the DLC yet, but even the base game alone can keep you entertained for hours and hours on end.

review_text: I think the controls were a bit messy at the start, after changing the controls it was awesome. Bosses were great, aiming for the achievements was also great, stopped playing at June of 2024 and probably will stop after no more updates, but the Noise update was awesome. It is challenging but not to hard nor easy, and it's easy to beat a normal level where you don't have to restart like 10 minutes when first playing of work. I only died twice do to time the entire playthrough.

author: Bradyherbst7
review_text:
Another Idie game that blows the AAA competition out of the water. This should be the bar for indie games.

Everything about it is great. It's funny, and stylistic. It's engaging and infinitely replayable. Everything from the in depth movement, to the bosses, and level design. 
Additionally if you enjoy games like Neon White, Doom, Celeste, or any other form of speed runner games, you should play this. Not to mention that it does it well. Another idie game that felt like it could be spedrun is RollerDrome. Super fun game, but it forced you to get a certain rank before progressing.I felt it made the game worse. Pizza Tower does it the right way and encourages you to get an S/P Rank, but doesn't require it.

It has its own style, and their style is beautiful. About story, it has a nice story and you can enjoy it. Your adventure, power of music, power of friendship... All i can say about the story is that its amazing. I think there is no need to talk about musics because my words are not powerful enough to describe this soundtrack. Gameplay is satisfying. author: Nove123
review_text:
What is this game is difficult to notice among many indie games, as it seems at first glance one figurative. But is it? Today I want to make a remark about what to look at it. Well, let's start with the visual, it's beautiful here, these words will be enough. And what about the gameplay has something to say. Firstly, he is strongly associated with music here and it is damn unusual in comparison with today's indie games. Secondly, its dynamism in some moments just rolls over, sometimes you don't even know where to hide in order to survive. The plot is here, but it is difficult to call it not childish, because it is built on friendship and mutual assistance. But in addition to the advantages in the game there are downsides, but rather they are connected with my preferences.
Firstly, the duration of the game is negligible, because it took me almost 2 hours to go through it. Secondly, there are too few music levels here, as they depend on the amount of music, but all music is not really them, therefore I see no reason to add so little music. And then there are some problems with complexity. Since it is at some points off scale, and in most cases average. If you warn us about the occurrence of epilepsy and you are aimed at a Danish audience, then why add casual mode, you'd better add a more complicated mode.
Summing up, I want to say, if you like the genre of dubstep music, electro and you want to have a nice evening, then this game is just born for you, since there is online and cooperative modes and answering the question: "Is the game worth the money?" I can answer: "Yes worth it!".

author: savvym
review_text:
Coop or competitive online game about making way for your railroads which you have to build fast. You control a character with basic movements and you only use two tools, one for wood and one for stone. Furthermore you can equip your train with extra wagons and improvements, such as dynamite producer, extra space, ghost wagons, jet pack and such.

GAMEPLAY 5/5
The game is divided by stages, so your goal in each one is to reach the final station by putting down the rails in front of your train. If you fail, the train will derail and game over. The players tend to block each other, even the terrain complicates movement. They can use predetermined icons for simple interactions.

GRAPHICS 3/5
Very simplistic, colorful and in later stage somehow confusing change of perspective. There are few models of character. There is a day and night cycle, during night each player has its own small light radius. Orientation and planning is important. The map moves slowly to the right towards the final station as the train moves, leaving the left side of the map covered but the player can wander off there. The main menu is nicely done controlled as if playing game itself.

REPLAY VALUE 5/5
The coop offers three difficulties and few modes. As you progress further, you have new fauna and flora, some is just annoying, some dangerous, some slows you down and some prevents you from advancement. You can collect some yellow things while running around. Each map is randomly generated seed.

MUSIC 5/5
It is soothing, little playful, good ambient sounds, not distracting from my objectives and nice at the same time.

HARDWARE REQUIREMENTS
Non-gaming.

HOW DIFFICULT
Normal and Hard. Gets really nerving when your team does a lot of mistakes.

HOW LONG TO FINISH
Competitive mode lasts for few seconds, depending on the player skills and speed. Other mode can be endless.

SIMILAR GAMES
Graphically: Kingdom series
Gameplay: Overcooked!, Minecraft

VERDICT 9/10
Entertaining.

Original coop multiplayer with simple controls and limited maps. It is like Minecraft from a top-down view with objectives, the map keeps track of your distance so when the game is over, you will see a presentation of all your railroad through the map which is a satisfying look.

Early access game with well implemented ideas. It is what it is. Time limit is crucial factor. Communication options could be improved together with additional view options, like zooming and disabling flip screen which I personally welcome.

author: ntorix

Pour moi un classique des roguelikes nerveux.
Le gameplay est vraiment kiffant et la multitude d'armes, de bénédictions et de modifications disponibles diversifient le gameplay a chaque tentative.

author: egeiscimen
review_text: Exhilarating combat, sharp writing, and a roguelike loop that never overstays its welcome. Supergiant at its absolute best.

author: matthew5326
review_text: One of the easiest games to recommend ever. This game was in early access for a long time, and received many updates and changes with the feedback of a large playtesting community, and it shows so well. The gameplay is genuinely so addicting and well-made, that conceptually i feel like i have some problems with this game that became irrelevant because its so enjoyable. Wonderful artstyle, music, characters, and story as well, but overall i will always remember this game for the sheer amount of fun it never ceases to be. Appeals to a massively broad audience and is near-universally adored.

author: J1mbo
review_text: The amount of time you last or if you even beat the game is determined by luck. However other than that complaint the game does require a good amount of skill. At the beginning of the game, you can pretty much go afk while you destroy a ship, however, as you progress it gets harder and harder to the point where you have to be glued to your screen making sure your ship is repaired and if you're targeting the most vital part of your enemy's ship according to your current situation. The game Spore would be a world better if it implemented some of this game's mechanics into its game.

author: HydrophobikFish

author: VahNabooty
review_text: Wonderful roguelike thats very fast paced and has a great amount of content. Gunplay is some of the best I've played in a game.

author: DeaDMeme
review_text:
Nuclear Throne is a brilliant example of everything and anything that a top-down rogue-like shooter should strive to be and have. It's a game in which you play as one of many unique and different characters, each with their own special attributes and abilities and fight through all the enemies on any given floor. On each floor, you find new guns ammo and sometimes secrets.
Your objective is to get as far as you can floor after floor, kill after kill, bullet after bullet. It's a very simple concept a mite more simple than other games that try and do this like Enter the Gungeon or Risk of Rain as they are a little more mechanically intensive than nuclear throne while this causes a slight lack of mechanical depth this is more than made up for in the simplistic fun the game offers. Everything from just shooting a new gun to destroying the nuclear throne itself feels good. out of the massive library of guns, you'll find not one doesn't feel good to shoot with and use. That's not to say that there aren't any bad guns as there are certainly some that are worse than others and others which are better. Which brings me to the next point of game balance.
All of the game balance is done very well in terms of the player's arsenal as the way the game handles it is by giving the player some of the worse guns early on and holding the good stuff till later on, and when I say good stuff I mean Gatling rocket launchers and cluster nuke guns. While this is done very fairly, the game is a rogue-like and relies on replay-ability, while the guns early on are for the most part bad if you are lucky you could just come across a heavy crossbow and other weapons a cut above the cloth from the first level standard.
In terms of the game's aesthetics, the pixel art is both wacky cool and imaginative with funny and unique art for the enemies and bosses. On the other hand due to the simplistic gameplay and the simple geometry of the rooms gameplay can get repetitive for some but I find that to be a factor more dependant on the player than it is the game.
Overall I think nuclear throne is a fantastic example of what a good roguelike shooter should be like, fun gameplay fantastic replayability and an encouragement to keep playing to experience all the content.

author: edgreencorp
review_text: Great game and an excellent innovative mechanics, the best and most addictive of the last years

author: maluigario
review_text:
TL;DR: Fun, hilarious, and cute. If you have had an iota of fun with a twin stick shooter or want to try one for the first time, GET THIS GAME.

DISCLAIMER: Got this game free on Epic Games.

I had seen this game from afar, never committed to buying it. I'd never even enjoyed a twin-stick shooter before. I don't think this has changed my opinion on the genre, but I LOVE this game.

Everything in this game is stylized to the max, with every enemy being a gun reference. The enemies are bullets that hold guns that shoot bullets, and your job is to shoot bullets at the bullets while dodging their bullets while not taking contact damage from the gun-weilding bullets. Sometimes your bullets are actually fish. Sometimes your gun has a mermaid tail. Sometimes it's a reference to a unique gun from some other media, like Halo or Hyper Light Drifter or Judge Dredd. And sometimes your gun is a bullet that shoots guns that shoots more bullets, so you can shoot guns full of bullets at the gun-weilding bullets.

The bosses are hysterically named and genuinely difficult to fight. There's a gorGUN, or AMMOconda or a king bullet **** on his flying throne of guns.

There is so much to unlock in this game. Besides your 4 starting characters, there are 4 more unlockable characters. There's an actual story in here worth digging for. There's like 4 different extra modifiers for different ways to play, like a Turbo mode that speeds everything up or a challenge mode that adds a random challenge to every room and boss.

The one and only beef I have with this game is that some of the quests you have to do to unlock everything can get a little tedious. And that's a small beef for something that a player not interested in unlocking EVERYTHING will not even endure. The fact that I could get some 40 hours of gameplay in what is essentially a roguelike with a small fixed number of floors before finding something tedious is a testament to how fun this game as a whole is. I've unlocked everything and I still play this regularly just for fun.

author: Thyi
review_text:
Eu até iria dar uma nota 9 para o Rogue Legacy 2. Ele é um jogo incrível. Passei muito tempo jogando-o com bastante prazer. E até mesmo hoje ainda jogo as vezes. Porém, não dá pra ignorar certas coisas que optaram por fazer no jogo. Mas, apesar disso, continua sendo um ótimo jogo.

A primeira coisa, é que o RL 2 em muitos aspectos é basicamente uma cópia do RL 1, mas com melhorias estéticas e mais polimento. Eu não joguei o 1, então, para mim isso não fez a menor diferença. Mas com certeza pra quem jogou, isso pode ter sido um grande problema.
Outras coisas que me incomodaram bastante durante a gameplay, foram algumas escolhes de design do jogo. A esquiva colidir com os inimigos e causar dano ao jogador não me parece correto. Apesar de que eu me acostumei com isso depois, ainda acho que deveria ser uma esquiva que realmente esquiva dos ataques, como na maioria dos jogos. A Cellar Door também exagerou na quantidade de elementos que podem causar dano ao jogador. São várias armadilhas, elementos do cenário, excesso de projeteis inimigos que, inclusive, alguns atravessam paredes. Além dos próprios inimigos, é claro, que causam dano com ataques e ainda com seu próprio contato físico.
Sobre as classes e ataques em geral, eu acho que ficou bem esquisito os ataques de algumas classes em certas ocasiões. O bárbaro, por exemplo, quase não tem dano aéreo, pois seu ataque no ar é muito fraco e ruim de controlar. Isso faz com que acertar inimigos no ar seja um GRANDE empecilho. A falta de direcionar o ataque para a direção que você quer atrapalha muito algumas classes, como mago, boxeador, assassino. Aliás, a classe assassino é uma das piores, por além do seu dano ser baixo, é terrível no ar.
Felizmente, no geral os talentos das classes são bons, e mudam bastante a gameplay. Já as magias... simplesmente não se encaixam bem no jogo. A maioria são sem sentido e ruim de usar. Algumas são muito melhores que outras. O Tiro Calcinante é basicamente melhor que qualquer uma das magias para o mago. E pra classes baseadas em dano físico, com exceção de algumas, as magias são muito dispensáveis.
Sobre a variedade de cenários e inimigos, eu acredito que seja outro ponto negativo. Só há 6 biomas. O que é muito pouco mesmo para um roguelite, que é um jogo que iremos jogar por horas e horas. Comparando com o Dead Cells, lá tem diversos biomas, e você não irá passar por todos na mesma run. Eu sinto que nele os mapas são bem menos repetitivos. O que dá uma sobrevida ao jogo. Já no RL 2, fica muito maçante o começo no Castelo, e depois o mesmo percurso. Sempre com os mesmos 6 biomas. Pra piorar, os chefes só enfrentamos uma vez por "finalização". E com isso, eu quero dizer que mesmo que você jogue várias runs, o chefe que você matou já era, e só vai enfrentá-lo novamente após finalizar a história, e de novo só depois que finalizar novamente a história, e assim por diante. Isso torna o jogo ainda mais repetitivo e um pouco maçante. E os inimigos serem basicamente os mesmos em diferentes biomas, porém "evoluídos", não ajuda nem um pouco. Realmente faltou uma maior variedade de inimigos. Até tem inimigos exclusivos de cada bioma, mas são minoria. E no geral, realmente é o mesmo inimigo com um visual um pouco mais parrudo e com golpes melhores.

Sobre a narrativa do jogo, eu sinto que foi muito deixada de lado. Basicamente quase toda a história principal é contada através de anotações. Pouquíssimas interações com NPC durante a run (acho que dá pra contar nos dedos). E pra variar, isso deixa a run ainda mais repetitiva. Fazendo um paralelo com Dead Cells, ou Hades, nesses jogos você encontra NPCs em cada run. E desenvolve uma narrativa através deles. É algo bem mais fácil de entender, e mais interessante do que apenas ler uma anotação que torna uma história simples em algo confuso de entender. Ao menos os NPCs do lobby são muito carismáticos, e interagem bastante, com diversas falas. Esse padrão deveria acontecer durante a run. Agregaria bastante.

Por fim, as melhorias e itens do jogo. É triste que eu finalizei a história do jogo e não fiz uma build completa com as armaduras. Ou seja, com os buffs máximos do set. Por exemplo, o set do Protetor dá destreza no primeiro e segundo nível, e chance de crítico no terceiro. Após finalizar, é possível conseguir armaduras de nível mais alto, e algumas eu acho que só são possíveis de obter no NG+. O que é uma pena, porque uma coisa tão legal ficou basicamente de fora da principal parte do jogo. Sobre as melhorias, são bem bacanas. Porém, a chance de crítico só passa a ser usada muuuito depois. Não faz sentido. O crítico desse jogo é basicamente só o crítico de perícia, que acontece numa situação específica. Pois conseguir chance de crítico aleatório, é só com bastante tempo de jogo.

review_text: I love roguelike games, this one is even better than the first part, kept everything good from the first part, improved and added several new features

author: Vulgrim
review_text:
I watched the game for a long time before buying it and saw its potential. Currently, it may not have a lot of possibilities, but as I mentioned - it has the potential for much more.
In my opinion, it is more fun to play than Slay the Spire, if only because of a more thoughtful system of improving cards (because we decide ourselves how we improve our creatures and spells) and the requirement of more frequent combinatorics. For me, an advantage (though probably not everyone likes it that much) is the lack of annoying RNG, which will quickly destroy our approach. We also have interesting multi modes and interestingly designed daily challenges. The soundtrack is also very nice.
Of course, as in any game of this type, we would like there to be even more cards, artifacts, enemies, etc. This is also the case, but I don't think the game will stop as it is.
In addition, I hope that in the future the creators will develop their game, which at the time of release seems to offer more than Slay the Spire after adding (years later) the fourth character.
After time, you can see the game is developing - there are new leaders, bosses and mutators of the game. Keep it up!

author: JxBest
review_text: If you enjoy rougelite/rougelike deckbuilders then you'll like this game as well. Coming from slay the spire this game is easy to get into and understand, until you unlock Covenant levels and the game becomes really challenging. Ive played alot of hours in this game and the replay value with the different deck combos keeps me very entertained. Overall consensus this game Is Very Good.

author: CompleteIdiot
review_text: Probably the best roguelike card game on the market right now. Quite fun and ultra addictive as expected. My main gripe with it is the enemy variety and end-game. Making broken decks is fun, but the creativity that was put into creating all sorts of different classes is lacking when it comes to the bosses and enemies. All of them basically feel like the same bullet-sponges. Just ramp up your attack and HP and you'll be fine.

author: Mirrorminx
review_text:
This is the most content-rich deckbuilder rogue like game out there, and has a huge breadth of interesting mechanics, choices, and difficulty that make it stand apart from it's competitors. Many reviews compare this to Slay the Spire, which is a great, but straightforward game. This game has a LOT more varied mechanics, strategies, and deck styles, with five factions, units & spell based strategies. Cards can be individually customized with upgrades, and refining your deck is about much more than just trimming your deck down to a lean machine (which is the optimal strategy in most other deck builders). While some cards are niche, every unit and card has a place in an interesting strategy, and the starting faction (Hellhorned) barely scratches the surface of what lies beneath.

Don't buy this if you don't like deck builders: while it is mechanically very different from Slay the Spire, the deck and cards still form the backbone of how you play. But truly, this game is genre-defining, it does so many things well, and after having played dozens of deck builders on mobile and pc, this is by far my favorite in this genre

author: JustinForgueims
review_text:
Awesome game!
Its secret is that makes everything simple. You learn through playing and every time you can reach further and have more and more options.
It's super rewarding because every run you unlock a few weapons, bonus, stages and/or characters.
You die every run, but you want more as the game is rewarding you for this death.
The runs are quite fast (15-30min) so it's a great game for people not plenty of time.
The level of characterization and improvement is high if you want to deep dive into the endgame builds.
The only drawback I found is that it relies too much on external content, as many weapon mechanics, evolutions and secrets are almost impossible to learn in-game.

author: Tiernandl
review_text: Generally a fun game in whitch I would highly recommend for gamers who are trying to have a relaxing experience.Also I would like to add that the price is fantastic for the value compared to other games.

review_text: Одна з найкращих ігор цього жанру. Всі комбінації зав'язані навколо класів, яких тут понад 40. При цьому гра дуже проста та ненапряжна.

author: HarleyMac
review_text: No button pushing, just move around the screen and gain weapons and skills between levels in this rogue-like type game.  Got it free this week, 11/28/24, on Epic games.  Gave it a shot and lost the next 3 hours of my life.  Its addictive.  There really isn't much to it, you just move around and try to dodge the monsters and build your character by buying skills with the stuff that drops off the massive amount of monsters you kill.  It is fun and addictive, but the downside of the game is it feels unrewarding.  You don't get any rewards for beating a run really except a few different templates to try and challenge yourself, like start off with +50 range and -50 dodge and you can only use 1 weapon, or something like that.  Its a fun game, but If I bought it, i'd be willing to pay a few dollars more to have some more features.  But I didn't buy it, I got it for free, so I really can't complain, but feel like they have a very solid game and it could have been more.  I really think its a 7.5, but I'll round up cause its fun.

author: marto
review_text:
This game is among the ones with the most "mind blown" occasions that I've played. It is quite deep, literally and as you discover new things about its mechanics.
I would call it a hard game because there are so many hazards that you can die to. You can't be aware of all of them all the time.
I guess the way it's built, the ultimate goal for any player is to make the breakthrough - become so powerful that you can go anywhere and do anything. Just don't step in a pool of teleportatium or polymorphine ;)

author: Valentin2227
review_text:
Après avoir découvert le premier Hades l’année dernier, Hades 2 était devenu automatiquement l’une de mes plus grosse attentes pour cette année et Hades 2 a clairement survolé et dépassé les attentes que j’avais autour de lui.


point positif

 - Bon commençons par le plus gros point fort de Hades 2 c’est sont système de combat, déjà que celui du premier était de très haut volé, celui de Hades 2 c’est tout simplement de l’art, j’ai rarement vu un système de combat aussi riche, profond, varié et maîtrisé dans ces mécaniques. J’ai beau avoir dépassé les 100h de jeu je trouve les combats toujours autant addictif et grisant, chaque run est vraiment différent à jouer en grande partie grâce a la multitude quasiment infini de build différents possibles ( armes de départ, bienfaits, carte de taro…).

- Il y’a beaucoup de nouveautés apportées par Hades 2 et elles sont quasiment toutes ultra kiffant que se soit l’ajout de la mécanique de magie, les cartes de taro, les infusions, les nouveaux dieux ou encore le fait d’avoir le choix entre 2 run différents au départ (enfer, surface)…

- Hades 2 vient aussi quasiment gommer l’un des défaut de Hades 1 qui pouvait devenir un peu répétitif notamment a cause du fait qui n’y avait "que" 4 régions et boss différents mais dans Hades 2 et l’ajout de la run à la surface avec ces régions et boss différents vient vraiment casser cette répétitiviter 

- Les nouvelles armes sont à la fois toutes ultra kiffant à manier mais aussi totalement différent dans leur manière de ce jouer.

- Tout les boss sont très stylé à affronter notamment grâce à leur musique et patern vraiment kiffant.

- Tout les musiques sont du miel pour les oreilles !!!!

- La DA du jeu est tout simplement somptueuse   


Point négatif

 - L’histoire est un peu moins bien écrite que dans Hades 1 , les dialogues et les personnages sont aussi un peu moins intéressants que ceux du première opus mais reste comme même cool à suivre

 - Tout les nouveautés de Hades 2 sont très cool sauf une : les épreuves du chaos que j’ai trouvé vraiment pas intéressante et sans intérêt 

- les boss finaux de Hades 2 sont très cool mais reste vraiment moins bien que celui de Hades 1 

Pour conclure Hades 2 est un jeu terriblement addictif, grisant et qui possède l’un des meilleurs système de combat que j’ai pu jouer. Hades 2 a parfaitement réussi à renouveler la formule initié par le premier opus en ajoutant plein de nouvelles mécanique. Hades 2 est tout simplement un très grand chef d’œuvre du jeux vidéo.

author: tom970827
review_text: 1200 hours+if i can only play one game in my life then hades 2 it iscan feel the love of game maker since early access

author: sapphicvalkyrja
review_text: Hades II improves on its predecessor mechanically, visually, structurally, and in terms of scope, but unfortunately its narrative and characters are a significant downgrade. Where Hades managed the Heraclean task of weaving together its story of love and forgiveness with a looping gameplay structure, Hades II lacks any sort of comparable thematic through-line and concludes in a way that makes the entire experience feel incoherentThe gameplay absolutely rules, but it was the innovative approach to narrative and character writing that made the original as special as it was

author: Nazrielau05
review_text:
[Early review]
I defeated Chronos for the first time! It took me like 20 hours to truly feel and grasp the game's combat mechanics, that is including my time to understand chronos' attack patterns. This game is simply **** presentation is otherworldy! The art style, animation, voice acting, soundtrack/sound design in general—this game grabs you into it's world and doesn't let go until you kill the Titan of **** course, in a Rogue-like dungeon-crawling game such as this one, the combat mechanics is what matters the most. This game's mechanics is incredibly deep. It has it's own sauces and quirks—it stands perfectly fine on it's own and when compared to the first game.Incredible game so far. Easy reccomendation to any fan of Hades 1, or any action Rogue-like enjoyer for that matter. You'll get your money's worth with this game. Hell, with this quality? you might feel like you're robbing the developers by not paying more—such is the experience of playing high quality Indie games.

[Post-game review]I fully finished the story campaign after 40+ hours! This game is wonderful—My perfect image of an action Rogue-like experience. Alongside Hades 1 itself as well as something like Dead Cells.I got no new inputs about the game honestly. The story is pretty good early and halfway through. I'm inclined to follow one of those people who aren't into the ending. The game's ending isn't bad of course, just badly executed.I actually don't care about the story. I know it's a weird thing to say about a Hades game—since it's one of the few reasons why Hades 1 was so beloved. But a story isn't what i look for in a game.What i look for in a game is; presentation like visual style, sound design, character designs, as well as the gameplay mechanics in general. Hades 2 delivers all of that with grace. And i for one, couldn't be more grateful.

author: itscajuntimep
review_text: A fun, addictive little game that will give you a big challenge. However I find the replay value to be mixed since its the same 4 stages which even with random generation it can be repetitive

author: PeakZach
review_text: Replay-ability is fantastic, the constant updates are a great benefit, and the music makes this rogue-like different and an interesting play element to keep you thinking and patient at the same time.

author: EvgeniLinuxUser
review_text: Brain-blasting mix of music, arcade and roguelike! Unfortunately I am inevitably killed at the initial levels. I really want to hear how the further levels sound, but my reaction is too slow  The first game load and calibration takes some time but the gameplay is fast and not forgiving. Works fine on Ubuntu 18.04. Notebook with Intel HD Graphics 4400 is enough.

author: DragonHeart000
review_text:
Crypt of the NecroDancer is a very innovative game that somehow manages to put together Roguelike dungeon games and rhythm games into one well polished and fun game.

So far in my playtime, I have found no bugs or issues or really even anything that felt unfair. The rules of the game make sense, are fair, are fun, and still manage to be challenging.

The inclusion of being able to add any song you want to the game really brings this game over the top. On top of that, they added support for the steam workshop for mods. Allowing customizability is always something games should do.

author: MimicTheShadows
review_text:
This game is severely underrated and very overlooked compared to many other top notch indie games.
Taking care of your cult is, while not all that complex, fun and provides some good downtime while preparing for your next crusade.
The combat is serviceable and does what it has too but it can get repetitive pretty fast. This was a lot worse in earlier versions of the game but has gotten better with the introduction of relics and heavy attacks. I’m sure the upcoming DLC will work to fix this major issue and if it does I’ll update this review,
Now if that was all I’d probably rate this game a 6 or a 7 but the big thing that really pulled me in was the lore.
The Story itself is fine. Most will not get much out of it other than a reason to kill the bosses and a means to an end, but a lot of the world building in this game is actually fantastic and has kept me intrigued for the last two years.
Now I want to avoid spoilers in this review so I won’t go into detail but I’m very excited for how the lore will get expanded upon in Woolhaven. 
Also the art and music are perfect for this game. I have no notes (other than the birds).
Overall, 7.5/10 experience that is worth a playthrough or two!

author: Nazrielau05
review_text:
This game's presentation is by far the spotlight here. The soundtrack is such a nice contrast to the rather violent visual effects this game has, that itself was already contrasted with the cartoonish/comicbook-ish art style. This combination creates an insanely well made package that sticks in my mind even compared to other games with the best of the best visual presentation.

The Rogue-like mechanics was implemented effectively here. With the inclusion of different weapons each run, different Tarot cards, and recently relics that i achieved. It's pretty much RNG-based mechanics like other Rogue-like games. The combat system feels nice as well, the rolling mechanics really forces the player to be patient and make a good position before making any move recklessly.

Another aspect of CotL is the Base building mechanics. Basically a simulator for a Cultist society. It's really fun! your death in the battle runs has consequences in the cult camp, it makes for a good balancing system for all the fighting sequences. It breaks the pacing nicely as well. Instead of one aspect of the mechanics over-taking the spotlight, these two sides of the same coin creates a shinny golden piece of currency. And you'd wanna keep these two sides in the back of your head to optimally playing through the title.

review_text: El mejor roguelike de la historia de momento. Para mi este juego es insuperable en todos sus ambitos, graficos, jugabilidad, rejugabilidad, la gestion de la secta. Es un juego que engancha mucho y de los mejores indies del mercado en consolas actuales. 10000% RECOMENDADO

author: SoulsGamer34
review_text: Лучший фанатский Соулс-Лайк. Лучше него нету ничего. Игра цепляет в начале своими механиками, и атмосферой которая полностью копирует мой любимый соулсборн - Бладборн. В игре много классных боссов, очень красочные локации, сюжет подается более понятно чем в других играх, но ничего страшного - Главное знать первоисточник, а именно книгу о Пинокио. В стиме я наиграл более 112 часов в эту игру, и ещё на Плейстейшн 5 прошел один раз. Игра идеальна во всех смыслах, и возможно я её такой называю из за моей любви к Бладборну, но всё же это мое мнение.

author: RockerKR
review_text: This is an excellent souls-like game inspired by the novel The Adventures of Pinocchio. The action unfolds across ten large, diverse, and creatively designed locations, each with its own unique atmosphere and distinct enemies. However, one drawback was the unbalanced progression system. Leveling up felt unrewarding, as enemies scaled in strength alongside the player’s stat increases. Some enemies dealt excessive damage and exhibited unpredictable, unrealistic movement patterns. I suppose this is typical of souls-like games. Overall, it’s an intriguing title.

author: MumenOnline
review_text:
I had a great time with Lies of P, I can easily recommend it to anyone that enjoys Souls-like games, and I consider it the best entry outside of FromSoftware’s catalogue. For people who struggle with Souls-like games, I’m a bit on the fence about whether this one is for you. On one hand, I found a lot of the bosses easy, but difficulty definitely ramps up with the later bosses and some of the tougher enemies throughout the levels.

The biggest issue of this game is definitely the level layouts themselves. Most of them aren’t necessarily bad, but they are simplistic, meaning there wasn’t any that knocked it out the park or felt special. Later game areas frankly become a pain, especially when you combine the uninteresting level design with the game throwing annoying enemies groups at you. Exploration feels unfulfilling, and Item pickups aren’t exciting unless they’re from a chest, otherwise they’re mostly forgettable.

The game is surprisingly fluid. It has quick manoeuvrability and familiar gameplay that feels right at home if you’ve played a Souls game before. Sekiro-like deflecting is also here, which builds an invisible stagger meter and can even break your enemy’s weapon. You will likely never have to grind in this game, with weapon materials being plentiful, and progression coming naturally as long as you spend your ergo (souls) after every boss.

author: WanderinMelmoth
review_text:
This is SUPERIOR SOULS.
Yes, it is better than anything From Soft has ever made. Why? Because the devs are not a$$holes! There are fair saves right in front of every boss room. THIS is excellent game design.
Atmosphere and world design are excellent and even beat Bloodborne. Fights are hard enough without the cheapness of FromSoft's games. The combat has actually tactics involved instead of simply memorizing enemy moves. FromSoft: take notes, you have met your master!

author: S3XU4LH34L1NG
review_text: A decent souls like with a very mysterious convoluted world. I liked my experience and the lack of handholding but the combat just isnt that snappy and the balance and playcement of the enemies is questionable at best. Also the endboss is bs.

author: Zeneko90
review_text: Nettes. Spiel es hat echt viel Spaß gemacht. Mehr davon! Nicht zu lang, nicht zu kurz. Genau richtig.

author: Flopjokdang
review_text: The soulslike Mortal Shell is quite similar to well known games of the genre, but feels completely different.  With a beautifully grim and gloomy atmosphere, it tempts you to explore it's maze-like surroundings. With interesting dialogue, mechanics and lore: lovers of the souls genre will be captivated by this interesting 12 hour adventure.

author: EduCLSS
review_text: Una copia muy mal hecha de los Souls (que ya de por sí tienen defectos notorios). En este caso nos encontramos con un juego con un sonido ambiental insoportable, el cual es un zumbido que te deja con dolor de cabeza. Las animaciones de combate son totalmente defectuosas, en muchos casos se bugea la esquiva de golpes y te deja totalmente vulnerable al ataque del enemigo (pasa muy frecuentemente). Respecto de la historia, totalmente ausente, no tiene sentido alguno. En la parte técnica está súper mal optimizado y hasta el día de hoy no logra funcionar decentemente por sobre los 30 fps. El entorno y los enemigos son sosos y repetitivos. En fin, un juego que en su tiempo tenía potencial, pero que terminó siendo decepcionante.

author: Wiezzel
review_text:
I tried to play it on Computer, the movement with Keyboard and mouse is utterly garbage.
When you press A or D the camera AGRESSIVELLY turns and if you are FORCED to counter act with your mouse, many times it just ignore it and turns even more. It can quickly turn into a spiral camera turning around because the design is just plain trash and there is really no defense for how bad it is.
Since the camera is really the the gate to play the game and without visibility there is not much that can be done, this game deserves a 1.

I gave 1 extra for  the graphics. They seemed nice, not mind blowing, and lacking detail, but they fit in the environment ( that is poorly designed to fight in) it is really nice to only* walk around.

There is a mind blowing amount of unstoppable cut scenes that are garbage as well. Like after the tutorial, the character SLOWLY gets out of the water taking all the time of the world and you slowly walk forward and then they make you press E to enter a tunnel as cinematic animation like, where you then press W for like 3 min straights while you crawl through a quiet ugly dumb tunnel.
Just so the devs Ego can present you  "Mortal Shell" on the bottom black banner .... as if anything so far was impressive. Maybe for kids under 10 that do not know any better.

The tutorial is also made abnormally slow. Too many waste of times part.

Now that all and all you wasted 80% of your time the first 1h doing utterly nothing but staring and waiting and pressing 1 button at a time, you can start walking around fighting the camera automatic adjustment mainly. You will never get used to it, I uninstalled the game after another 30 min as it was mind blowing stupid how there is no setting to change that.

After all of this, there is some fighting. Fighting is VERY easy and you will just die early on for random things you are just not aware of ( there is no intro to new enemies ) you just going to die and repeat the last 10 min gameplay, Really a design around wasting your time, not giving fun.

The fighting itself is boring, very simple, not crazy or nice action.
Regular Dodge and slash and dodge and spamm slash and your enemy cant do anything or do the Hardened thing any time. I am really not a good player and never play soul like, but this was piss easy and I tried Dark souls 1 and I actually quit this one because it was hard not trash like Mortal shell.

At no point waste your MONEY and even less your time on this game.
Devs need to learn how to design basic before doing this.

author: DUCKMANBILL
review_text:
Piece of **** game made artificially longer by clunky and occasionally unusable mechanics which have not been thought out in the slightest. Healing is absolutely terrible, the only way you can really heal is by parrying which in itself is terrible because parrying has a windup animation making it slow and incredibly difficult to use.
It has a great tone and the character and boss designs look fantastic, but I can't honestly recommend this considering that the gameplay does not hold up in the slightest.
Just another Dark Souls clone that does not have enough budget, talent or whatever it may be to pull it off.

author: Young_Fawn
review_text:
A Solid Souls-Like Entry

Thymesia, for me, can be described as a strange combination of Bloodborne, Nioh and Sekiro.

Aesthetically it looks like Bloodborne and is about as fast paced.
Combat is a bit like Sekiro, with a strong emphasis on parrying, especially on boss fights, if you don't learn to Parry, the Bosses will put you down very quickly. It's also not hard to learn, a lot of complaints in reviews I see are people comparing it to Sekiro and then complaining about parrying? Hello?
The main Nioh aspect of it is the Plague Weapons which are a variety of different special attacks you can use and also the mission select, the game is not open world like Sekiro and Bloodborne, but level based.

The game manages to succeed in the way that all games should, it's simply very fun to play.
The enemy design is pretty basic but even the most bog standard guy can mess you up if you're not careful or you get too overzealous in your attacks.

One thing I liked is how each enemy has basically two health bars, armour and hp. You need to get the armour down so you can get access to the HP and use different attacks for each, if you spend too long dilly-dallying and not applying enough pressure, their armour bar begins to regenerate. I think it's pretty neat.

The side-quests are a must, yeah they're in the same level as you did before, similar to how Nioh's side-quests work, but you get a lot from them and some of the Bosses are strictly in Side-Quests only, so I'd highly recommend doing them, you also need their "Cores" for some of the different endings.

I didn't really have many problems with the game, I see people complaining about frame rate drops but I only had that for the first 10% of the first mission, it was absolutely not a consistent flaw.

Bosses are like how they are in most games of this genre, you get beat enough times to learn the attack patterns and then it just becomes about smashing them once you've got it down.

The story isn't told to you straight up, it's all done through passages and notes you find on the ground, which give you an idea of some of the history of the level and how things came to be. Again, not to keep referring to other reviews, but I don't understand why people are saying it's a comparable to Sekiro or Bloodborne and then complaining that the story isn't told to you in an obvious manner. Isn't that one of the reasons those former games were praised? Everything seems a bit hypocritical.

I guess my only complaint is that the game is quite short, you can probably finish the game in around 6-8 hours if you do all the side quests as well, but the game is only £20 so it's not that strong an argument.

I highly enjoyed my time playing Thymesia, maybe I'll go back and get some of the other endings, it was a good little experience and I really hope in a few years we'll see a sequel which is longer with a few extra mechanics added to the game. It's a solid entry into the genre and it is absolutely one of the betters ones on the market outside of Fromsoft games.

For what it is, it's a great game; something to keep you occupied for a day or two with a little bit of replayability but not a whole lot. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a game to scratch that souls-like itch which a lot of us have.

8/10, a great game for what it is and you'll have a lot of fun playing it.

Also: Abuse the dagger, it's OP.

author: Mixtrix
review_text: Una maravilla lo recomiendo me encanto, es un juego chiquito desarrollado por un estudio pequeño, un juego con fallas y aciertos, unos combates de jefes geniales menos 1 que no me gusto, el escenario la verdad a mi me gusto y la variedad de enemigos me parece aceptable solo que el patron de ataques de ellos no varia, en cuestion de armas y eso pues no hay mucho jaja perooo pero lo compensa con un arbol de habilidades genial que permite personalizar al personaje a tu forma de jugar, la historia como en casi todo soulslike vale pepino c:, solo se me hizo en falta que los personajes tuvieran voces y talvez cinematicas pero meh, lo recomiendo denle la oportunidad a ver si tenemos un thymesia 2 c:

author: ErayTellezi
review_text:
Soulslike oyun açlığı çekenlerin şifa niyetine tüketmeleri gereken bir iş. Büyük çaplı değil, basit ve kısa bir oyun. Ama yaptığı işi çok iyi yapıyor. Karakter ve silah gelişimi olsa da rpg elementleri çok az. Bir tane silahınız var. Ancak özel yeteneğiniz sayesinde düşmanlarınızın silahlarını bir defaya mahsus çalıp kullanabiliyorsunuz. Böylelikle ondan fazla silahı kullanmış oluyorsunuz. Bu da oyuna souls oyunlarında olmayan bir element eklemiş.

Bir diğer şey düşmanlarınıza vurduğunuzda canlarının azalması ancak pençe ile vurmadığınızda yaralarının iyileşip geri dolması. Bu yüzden normal saldırılarınızı yaptıktan kısa bir süre sonra bir kaç kez de pençe saldırısı yapmanız gerekiyor. Bu da yavaş ve defansif değil agresif oynamak zorunda olmanız demek. Ki oyunun oynanışı da bunu destekliyor. Epey hızlı bir karakterimiz var. Ne kadar hızlı olduğumuzu oyunun son boss'u olarak kendimiz gibi birisi karşımıza çıktığında anlıyoruz. Beni bir kaç saat uğraştırdı açıkçası.

Oyun atmosferi ve görselliği güzel. Müzik yok gibi bir şey. Harita dizaynı fena değil. Bir bölüme sondaki boss'u kesip gidiyorsunuz. Ama o bölümde keşfedecek küçük yerler falan var. Üst katlar vesaire. Öyle dümdüz koridorda ilerlemiyorsunuz.

Neticede iş görür derecede bir oyun. Çok beklenti olmadan oynanabilir. Türe eklediği bir kaç yaratıcı fikir de cabası.

author: Midlanejunkie
review_text: In my opinion the perfect Soulslike. The combination of new ideas (white and green bar, weapons, talent tree) and good old mechanics (deflect and dodge) make it really fun. It‘s fast pace, it‘s extremely hard. Bosses are designed nicely, graphics are great. Hope there will come more!

author: ErayTellezi
review_text:
Fransız Devrimi'nde mekanik bir robotu yönettiğimiz, görsel tasarımıyla göz doldursa da dövüş mekanikleri çok keskin olmayan, bu nedenle bir yerden sonra sıkan soulslike oyun.

Ben parry yapabildiğimiz yelpazeye benzer şeyi kullandım. Element hasarı veren, uzun menzilli olan silahlar da vardı ama bu oyun çok hızlı olması nedeniyle parry yapmak keyifli olur gibi geldi. Karakterimi de ona göre dancer sınıfından seçtim zaten.

Oyunun ortalarına kadar çeşitlilik iyi gidiyordu aslında. Yeni düşman çeşitleri geliyor, yeni yetenekler geliyor, kullanmasam da yeni silahlar ediniyordum. Ama ortalardan sonra özellikle yeni düşman çeşidi gelmemeye başladı. Boss'lar farklıydı bir tek. Ancak onların da çok kolay olduğunu söylemem gerek. Çoğunu tek denemede geçtim. Böyle soulslike oyun mu olur? Boss'lar hiç agresif değiller. Çok az vuruyorlar, genelde mal gibi vuruşlarınızı yiyip duruyorlar. Boss savaşlarını hiç beğenmedim. Bir önceki souls oyunum Thymesia'nın fersah fersah gerisinde bu anlamda.

Yan görevler falan da vardı ama oyun çok sarmadığı için uğraşmadım. Hatta son 2 bölümü etraftaki düşmanlarla hiç uğraşmadan direkt boss'lara koşarak geçtim.

Netice itibariyle olmak istediği şeyi tam olamamış ,eksik bir oyun.

author: Ginger_Avenger
review_text: ((**To get this out of the way at the start, I played this on the Steamdeck. It isn't verified, but the only issue noted was small text. I would add another issue:  this game for me crashed quite a bit in the later game locations.))  REVIEW:   This game is hard to review. I love Action RPGs, and this studio's last title, Greedfall, was alright and had some interesting ideas, particularly with the setting and basic story. And that might be Steelrising's best aspect- the setting is a really nice looking revolution era France instead of the typical dark fantasy of similar games. The combat and builds are alright, but had all the flow of Dark Souls 2 (and even has the two-tiers for healing items). This was good for me, as that is the only Dark Souls game I've managed to finish so far. Still, it's really rough around the edges, and the side missions were mostly bland and were piled on at a certain point before the late game rather than more evenly placed throughout (or they would be available but you couldn't advance them until you advanced the main game when it returns to that location anyway). Still, I enjoyed it enough to play it thru to the end, so for me, that counts for a lot.

author: kiozen
review_text: *Among Us* is a simple yet captivating social deduction game that has taken the world by storm. Set aboard a spaceship, players must complete tasks while trying to uncover who among them is the Impostor—a player secretly working to sabotage and eliminate the others without being detected. Player interaction is central to the experience, with moments of tension and accusation that create a unique and engaging **** visual design is minimalist but effective, featuring colorful characters and simple maps that allow players to focus on the gameplay. The mechanics are accessible to everyone, which has contributed to its massive popularity, especially among friends and families. The excitement of *Among Us* lies in the discussions and bluffing during meetings, where players attempt to convince others of their innocence or shift suspicion onto others.Regular updates to maps and game modes add variety, though the gameplay can feel repetitive after extended sessions. The multiplayer experience—especially with voice chat—is the game’s core strength, making each match a fresh and unpredictable experience.

author: ZAPA
review_text: Marvel Rivals might just be the biggest challenge Overwatch 2 has ever faced. By bringing the hero shooter genre into the Marvel Universe, it delivers a thrilling experience with a full roster of iconic superheroes to play as. The game makes a strong effort to stay true to its comic book roots, successfully crafting a unique and engaging experience for players. Since its release, I haven’t been able to put it down. Initially, I picked it up as a backup title for when Overwatch lost its spark, but it’s completely flipped my expectations—there’s something strangely addictive about it. The developers prioritize fun over rigid meta compositions, which significantly enhances the game’s playability and keeps things fresh.

author: Sanastusa
review_text:
Demons are invading your world of Arkesia. Cities and settlements being destroyed and countless deaths. They are searching for hidden relics of the past called Arks. Arks are the only thing with the power to defeat the darkness and bring balance to Arkesia. Hired as a bodyguard for a group of treasure hunters, you stumble your way into fate’s hands. Are you the hero who can find the lost arks?
A free-to-play massively multiplayer online action role playing game (MMOARPG) that released in the east in 2019. Through a partnership with developers and Amazon, a western release was put into the works and came out last month with a huge success.
To start because it will be brought up to anyone who talks about Lost Ark. If it's free-to-play, does that mean it's pay-to-win? In short, Yes. If you are the type of gamer who wants to just throw your credit card on a game to rush to the end content, you can do that. But that will not take away the enjoyment **** for others who choose to play without dropping loads of cash.
With the build up to the launch of Lost Ark, I ignored the hype because I didn’t think it would interest me. Knowing most free to play games offer a little enjoyment but quickly fall off for other games. The day of launch I watched a couple streamers play the game and after a couple hours of background watching I figured I would tip the toe into the water…not knowing I would be **** in and loving every minute.
I describe Lost Ark as a melting pot. It takes game themes from across the field and implements them in a great way all into one game. The story is good and captivating through Arkesia. Big cinematic events happening through the quest lines of different lands. The world is beautiful and a treat to explore by land or sea.
In combat you will easily be swarmed by monsters and feel the legion breathing down your neck but your skill set of flashy (anime-esque/diablo) moves will make you feel like an unstoppable badass. Blood and gore splattering across the detailed environments while you collect your loot.
You want Monster Hunter? They have Guardian Raids. Solo or a party of 4 can take on a variety of difficult guardians that limit normal functions in the game. Limited amount of revives/items while also adding in a time constraint to push your team. Too many mistakes with accidental deaths and it’s a failure.
Do you want challenging content? Abyssal dungeons/raids that focus more on a boss's mechanics than standing around swinging a sword aimlessly. For example the second dungeon has a necromancer and if you fail to collect the correct orbs, he will revive and receive an increase to his abilities making the fighter harder and harder. Kill him all you want, but if you can't communicate or understand a fight, you won’t survive.
You want to make multiple characters because of all the neat classes? Lost Ark is extremely alt friendly. Separate from character level there is an accumulated roster level for your account. Most rewards will be gained on one character but forever shared with your roster. It's even designed for alternate characters to do daily or basic activities to funnel materials to your main character for vertical progression of gear.
You want to fight other players? It has PVP combat that is designed to equalize gear and abilities when you enter into the arena. To balance players on a similar battlefield giving anyone a fighting chance.
On the other spectrum of horizontal content, there is an abundance. Varies collection systems with separate reward tracks to keep any completionist busy. A card system that captures the feeling of opening random packs in a real life trading card game. I get side tracked more with horizontal systems. I forget I need to improve my gear and advance through the story. It's rare for a game to nail that to such a degree.
The game isn't perfect by any definition. It has small flaws depending on the type of gamer you see yourself as. If racing to the end game is your cup of tea it will be a long process because upgrading your gear is a grind. Coming into the game new with no understanding of the systems is overwhelming. These systems came out slowly in Korea over the games development and with the western release we received them all at once. A little bit of reading or youtube videos can help give you the fundamentals of how the systems work.
For what the game has delivered, I am hooked. I'm close to reaching over 200 hours with the game only being out for a little over a month. I'm in for the long haul and excited to see more classes and cosmetics to be released into the game. I still have story quests to work through and the collections are keeping me itching to find the next hidden seed of Arkesia.
Story:  8 / 10
Gameplay:  10 / 10
Visual/Audio: 9 / 10
Entertainment: 9 / 10
Controls: 7 / 10
Final Grade: A

author: LT_Gruber
review_text:
Great game, but too hard and chaotic for me.

I liked Dota 2. It’s mechanics, variation and tension is a unique concept and I enjoyed it very much. I especially liked it’s balance.

In Dota 2, two teams, each up to 10 players, battle it out on a map. Their goal is to destroy the “Ancient” of the other team. This is a large, bulky structure. Each team can choose their own unique hero, 4 skills and choose if they want to play a support character or an attack character.

The attack character specializes in damage and destruction, while the support character focusses on healing, buffs and utilizations. At the start of each match, a little time is given to the players in the team to discuss tactics.

Along the way to the enemy base, various monsters spawn on the road. This monsters do not attack until you do first. They drop currency, which a player can use to buy items in the various little shops around the map. There are also some boss monsters, which drop special items, some of which can increase damage, allow a resurrection and much more.

The graphics in Dota 2 are nice and colorful. The environments on the maps are detailed and full of life and although simple, it has a certain charm. The only problem for me with the graphics, are the various effects of magic, explosions, hits, elemental attacks that blast in your screen during heavy combat, making me lose overview of the situation sometimes.

The sound and ambient music is great and adds to the experience. When **** hits the fan, it can be a little chaotic, but overall, nothing to complain here.

The mechanics, menu’s and action bars are a little confusing and need some time to get used to. The learning curve is a little steep here, and some training matches are certainly recommended. The way the game is supposed to be played (with the right tactics that is), takes even longer and in the beginning, many noob mistakes will be made. Certain items are used in the wrong moment, certain skills have been used too early, that kind of stuff.

Like mentioned, the best part of Dota 2, is its balance. Every player has equal chance of winning. If a player is stronger than you, or kills you with two hits, it is probably because they risked their lives while getting some unique items from monsters on the road. The magic attacks drain mana, which recharges over time. This way, the game prevents spamming the same attack multiple times, keeping it fair.

I liked Dota 2 and it’s mechanics a lot better than League of Legends. There is more balanced gameplay, more tactics (in my opinion) and, because you play in teams, there is more coordination and teamwork.

The only problem, and reason, I stopped playing, is (once again) my lack of skill with this kinds of games. I do like them, and surely want to try them out, however, this kind of intense, fast and “professional” games are not for some hours of relaxation. So in the end, I just cherished the few happy memories I had with this game and moved on.

In terms of gameplay, mechanics and overall feel however, I would certainly recommend this game.

author: midna2003
review_text: The best game I've ever played. The only game that I could play for 8 hours a day for the rest of my life without feeling bored. In fact, I had to stop playing because this game is so fun that it overshadowed everything else in my life. author: Pocnias
review_text: Les dix premières heures dans Warframe posent l'ambiance générale du jeu. Vous contrôlez une Warframe, entité organo-mécanique qui dispose de pouvoirs afin de libérez le Système Origine (notre bon vieux système Solaire). Le jeu est simple à prendre en main au début puis devient de plus en plus complexe au fur et à mesure de l'avancement dans l'histoire. D'aucun qualifierait Warframe de Pay2win or je dirais que vous pouvez ne rien dépenser dans le jeu. Seulement si vous financez des gros studios pour du COD pourquoi pas un studio de taille moyenne pour du Warframe ? Les seuls achats possibles ne vous avantagent pas par rapport aux autre joueurs mais vous permettent soit de progresser plus vite soit de pimper votre vaisseau ainsi que votre Warframe.
